encodingDesc.p: This document is a simplified "true-to-text" XML version of The Sea Voyage based on Pennsylvania State University's annotated copy of the 1647 Beaumont & Fletcher first folio. Major textual elements and attributes have been captured based on how they appear in the folio. Whenever possible, editorial interventions have been minimalized or avoided entirely. This document is meant to serve as a pedagogical tool by which students of Early Modern literature can learn to construct edited XML versions of the play.

front.head: This cast list has been adapted from the 1679 folio edition of Beaumont and Fletcher's Fifty Comedies and Tragedies. Spelling has been regularized based on how names appear in the dialogue, and new descriptions have been supplied.

castGroup.head: Gentlemen: used in stage directions to refer to an undefined collection of characters that may include one or all of the members of the group "Gentlemen."
general term referring to other passengers

castItem.roleDesc: banished from his country; French Lord looking to buy land and lordship in a new country

castGroup.head: Sailors: used in stage directions to refer to an undefined collection of characters that may include one or all of the members of the group "Sailors."
lower class; workers of the crew

castItem.roleDesc: a woman aboard the ship; under the protection of Albert
leader of the female commonwealth; a firm protector of the commonwealth
daughter of Rosella; raised by only women (aka, the commonwealth)

div.stage: A Tempest. Thunder and lightning.Thunder and lightning: In early modern plays, the stage direction "thunder and lightning" was very common, and the effects of thunder and lightning produced in a variety of different ways. In this play, it's assumed that the stage direction "thunder and lightning" is directly linked to a storm, but this was not always the case in many early modern plays (Dessen and Thomson, 231). Making the sounds of thunder and lightning could have been achieved through drums, flashes of fire, and fireworks. These types of stage directions were often created in the tiring house, as they were either directed toward or written by the bookkeeper who would then produce the stage effect on cue (Thomson, 14). In many cases, the effects of thunder and lightning were linked to the supernatural, and accompanied figures such as devils and witches, who would ascend from a trapdoor that signified the underworld. An audience would expect something supernatural when this particular effect occurs (Thomson, 11).

lg.l: Lay her aloofaloof: to the windward side! The sea grows dangerous!
How it spits against the clouds, how it caperscapers: dances or leaps,
And how the fiery element frights it back! Lightning.
There be devils dancing in the air, I think.
I saw a dolphin hang i'th' horns of the moon
Shot from a wave—Hey day! Hey dayHey day: exclamation!

How she kicks and jerks!How she kicks and jerks: It's important to remember that a performer in early modern plays could have expected to perform in a venue that was "a rectangular, flat, largely empty stage [with] nosets in the modern sense" (Syme, 112). Thus, we can assume that there was not actually a physical ship on stage. Therefore, in order to portray some sort of sea voyage, the use of ropes, tackle boxes, and other sailing equipment could have aided the impression of being at sea, with characters pulling on cords found in the tiring house. The stage of the play was seen as the deck, the tiring house as the cabin of the ship, and the balcony as the mast or the lookout area. During this play, it's also clear that the characters on the boat are fighting against strong waves; this illusion could have been made by the characters acting wild and hysterical (McInnis, 118).
Down with the main mast, lay her at hulllay her at hull: float or drift with wind or current,
Furl up all her linens, and let her ride it out.
She'll never brookbrook: tolerate it, Master.
She's so deep laden that she'll bulgebulge: spring a leak; also, swell.
Hang her.
Can she not buffetbuffet: beat back, contend with with a storm a little?
How it tosses her! She reels like a drunkard.
We have discovered the land, sir.
Pray, let's make in. She's so drunk, else,
She may chance to cast upcast up: vomit all her ladinglading: cargo.
Land in, land in. We are all lost else, lost and perished.
Steer her astarboard there.
Bear in with all the sail we can. See, Master,

See! What a clap of thunder there is,The special effects used during live performances in early modern England would depend heavily on the budget of the playhouse; they could range from austere and simple to grand and elaborate (Syme, XXX). Different effects such as drums, the firing of canons, and even fireworks could have been used to give the illusion that the actors and audience were actually in the center of a raging tempest.Thunder.
What a face of heaven; how dreadfully it looks! Sailor 2 looking up.
Thou rascal, thou fearful rogue, thou hast been praying,
I see't in thy face. Thou hast been mumbling
When we are split, you slave. Is this a time
To discourage our friends with your cold orisonsorisons: prayers?
Call up the boatswainboatswain: a ship's officer in charge of equipment. Sailor 1 beckons Boatswain from off-stage. How it storms—hollaholla: an exclamation calling for attention or to cease!
What shall we do, Master?
Cast over all her ladinglading: cargo? She will not swim
An hour, else.

div.stage: Enter Albert, Franville, Lamure, Tibalt Du-Pont, and Morillat.

lg.l: The storm is loud! Thunder and lightning.
We cannot hear one another!
What's the coastWhat's the coast: i.e. What coastline is it?
We know not yet. Shall we make in?
What comfort, sailors?
I never saw, since I have known the sea,
(Which has been this twenty years) so rude a tempest.
In what state are we?
Dangerous enough, Captain.
We have sprung five leaks, and no little ones—
Still rage—besides, her ribs are open,
Her rudder almost spentspent: used up, worn out. Prepare yourselves
And have good courages. Death comes but once,
And let him come in all his frights.
Is't not possible
To make in to'th' land? 'Tis here before us.
Here hard byhard by: very near, sir.
Death is nearer, gentlemen,
Yet do not cry. Let's die like men.
Shall'sShall's: Shall we hoist the boat outhoist the boat out: put out the rowboat
And go all at one castat one cast: in one movement? The more the merrier.
You are too hasty, Monsieur.
Do ye long to be i'th' fish market before your time?
Hold her up there.
Oh, miserable fortune!
Nothing but horror sounding in mine ears,
No minute to promise to my frighted soul.
Peace, woman!
We ha' storms enough already; no more howling.
Gentle, Master.
ClapClap: Place in custody this woman under hatcheshatches: half-doors on a deck.
Prithee, speak mildly to her.
Can no help?
None that I know.
No promise from your goodness?
Am I a god? For heaven's sake, stow this woman.
Go! Take your giltgilt: thinly layered in gold prayer book
And to your business. WinkWink: Close your eyes and die.
There an old haddock stays for yeThere ... stays for ye: The implication is that fish wait for her in the ocean, or perhaps under decks (Bourne)..
Must I die here in all the frights, the terrors,
The thousand several shapes death triumphs in,
No friend to counsel me—?
Have peace, sweet mistress.
No kindred tears upon me—oh, my country!—
No gentle hand to close mine eyes?
Be comforted. Heaven has the same
Power still, and the same mercy.
Oh! That wave will devour me!
Carry her down, captain,
Or by these hands I'll give no more direction.
Let the ship sink or swim, we ha' ne'er better luck
When we ha' such stowagestowage: cargo as these trinkets with us,
These sweet sin-breeders. How can heaven smile on us
When such a burden of iniquityiniquity: i.e., the stowage

Lies tumbling like a potion in our ship's belly?These sweet ... ship's belly?: The "sweet sin breeders" the shipmaster is referring to are women (here, specifically, Aminta, as she is the only woman on the boat). The shipmaster believes that everyone on the ship is going to die because they won't have any help from the heavens, and he blames this entirely on Aminta. Many times, women were denied passage on ships; if they happened to be on board, they were either a captive, a slave, or being forced to marry (Moore, 318). In line XXX, it becomes clear that Aminta has been captured by Albert, and that he has forced her to be on his ship for his own pleasure. Ironically, Aminta is only on the ship because of him, yet she is still being blamed for the dangerous storm.

div.stage: Exit Master, Boatswain, Sailors, Morillat, Lamure, and Franville.

lg.l: Away with her, and if she have a prayer
That's fit for such an hour, let her say't quickly
And seriously.
Come. I see it clear, lady. Come in,
And take some comfort. I'll stay with ye.
Where should I stay? To what end should I hope?
Am I not circled round with misery?
Confusions in their fullfull: i.e., a more fully felt or accumulated heights dwell about me.
Oh, Monsieur Albert, how am I bound to curse ye

If curses could redeem me! How to hate ye!Oh, Monsieur ... to hate ye!: In the 1647 text of the play, question marks are used to punctuate "Oh ... redeem me" and "How ... ye," but sometimes, in the seventeenth century, compositors would use question marks where we would use exclamation points today (Jackson, 549). Thus, the lines (as presented here) illustrate Aminta's raging anger and hatred for Albert if their question marks are meant to be interpreted as exclamation points. Question marks in this scene give off a completely different meaning: they would account for Aminta's confusion as to whether she should curse and hate Albert. Regardless, one cannot be sure as to when Aminta exactly falls in love with Albert, but it's crucial to consider that she is ultimately his prisoner before their love blossoms.
You forced me from my quiet, from my friends—
Even from their arms—that were as dear to me
As daylight is, or comfort to the wretched.
You forced my friends from their peaceful rest.
Some your relentless sword gave their last groans—
Would I had there been numbered—
And to Fortune's never-satisfied afflictions
Ye turned my brother and those few friends I'd left
Like desperate creatures to their own fears
And the world's stubborn pitties. Oh merciless!
Sweet mistress—
And whether they are wandered to avoid ye,
Or whether dead and no kind earth to cover 'em;
Was this a lover's part? But heaven has found ye,
And in his loud voice, his voice of thunder,
And in the mutiny of his deep wonders,
He tells ye now: ye weep too late.
Let these tears tell how I honor ye.
Ye know, dear lady, since ye were mine,
How truly I have loved ye, how sanctimoniouslysanctimoniously: pure or holy in character
Observed your honor. Not one lascivious word,
Not one touch, lady—no, not a hope that might not render me
The unpolluted servant of your chastity.
For you I put to sea to seek your brother—
Your captain, yet your slave—that his redemption,
If he be living where the sun has circuit,
May expiate your rigorrigor: harshness, sternness and my rashness.
The storm grows greater. What shall we do?
Let's in,
And ask heaven's mercy. My strong mind yet presagespresages: predicts, gives warning:
Through all these dangers, we shall see a day yet
Shall crown your piouspious: pitiful, devoted, faithful hopes and my fair wishes.

div.stage: Enter Master, Sailors, Gentlemen, Boatswain, and Surgeon.

lg.l: It must all overboard. Master lifting goods.
It clears to seaward mast.
Fling o'er the ladinglading: cargo there, and let's lighten her— Master throwing goods.
All the meat, and the cakes, we are all gone else—
That we may find her leaks and hold her up!
Yet save some little biscuit for the lady
'Til we come to the land.
Must my goods over too?
Why, honest Master? Here lies all my money,
The money I have wrackedwracked: raked, i.e. accumulated; possibly also wrecked by usuryusury: moneylending, often at excessive rates
To buy new lands and lordships in new countries
'Cause I was banished from mine own.
I ha' been this twenty years a-raising it.
Out with it.
The devils are got together by the earsgot together by the ears: fallen out, gathered to fight and who shall have it,
And here they quarrell in the clouds.

I am undone, sir.I am undone, sir.: On board this ship, there is a very interesting mix of characters from various social classes. Three of the men—Lamure, Franville, and Morillat—are French lords. In the early modern period, clothing helped establish a person's identity and located their position in a variety of categories ranging from gender, class, nationality, and religion (Lublin, 10). Thus, when Lamure's clothes and goods are thrown overboard, his response is that he feels completely ruined and destroyed (i.e. "undone"). Although this may seem dramatic to the modern reader, these characters experience a loss of material goods as a loss of identity. Furthermore, because Lamure is a self-made man (lines XXX), he loses the noble identity he has created for himself and is now seen as equal to those of a lower class that he spent "twenty years" trying to buy his way out of.
And be undone, 'tis better than we perish.
Oh, save one chest of plateplate: gold or silver coin!
Away with it lustilylustily: with pleasure or vigor, sailors—
It was some pawn that he has got unjustly—
Down with it low enough, and let crabs breed in't.
Over with the trunks too. Master throwing chest.
Take mine and spare not.
We must over with all.
Will ye throw away my lordship
That I sold, put it into clothes and necessaries
To go to sea with?
Over with it. I love to see a lordship sink.
Sir, you left no wood upon't to buoy it up.
You might have saved it, else.
I am undone forever.
Why, we are all undone. Would you be only happy?
Sir, you may lose too—
Thou liest. I ha' nothing but my skin,
And my clothes, my swordhere, and my self, Tibalt pulling out sword.
Two crownscrowns: British coins with a value of five shillings in my pocket, two pair of cards, Tibalt pulling goods out of pockets.

And three false dice.three false dice: Among Tibalt's listed possessions are "false dice," which are trick or weighted dice. Used as a prop, they are a physical manifestation for the actor to demonstrate the kind of wayward person that Tibalt is. And if the dice are not shown on stage and are instead just mentioned by name only, then it grants a quick snapshot of someone who values a handful of cheat dice as some of the things he keeps with him when he has so few possessions: "skin," "clothes," "sword," "self," "two crowns," "two pair of cards," and "three false dice" (lines XXX-XXX). His possessions portray him as a kind of traveling vagabond, a drifter that goes town to town and makes a living by gambling and violence. I can swim like a fish,
Rascal, nothing to hinder me.
In with her of all handsof all hands: on the part of everyone.
Come, gentlemen; come captain; ye must help, all.
My life now for the land;
'Tis high, and rocky, and full of perils.
However, let's attempt it.
Then cheer lustilylustily: with pleasure or vigor, my heartsmy hearts: term of address often used in consideration of bravery.
Yes, 'tis a ship! I see it now, a tall ship!
She has wroughtwrought: worked lustilylustily: with pleasure or vigor for her deliverance;
Heaven's mercy, what a wretched day has here been!
To still and quiet minds that knew no misery
It may seem wretched, but with us, 'tis ordinary.
Heaven has no storm in store, nor earth no terror,
That can seem new to us.
'Tis true, Nicusa, if FortuneFortune: Roman goddess of luck were determined
To be wantonwanton: undisciplined, unjust, abnormal and would wipe out the stories
Of men's miseries. Yet we two living,
We could cross her purpose, for 'tis impossible
She should cure us. We are so excellent in our afflictions
It would be more than glory to her blindnessblindness: in this usage, ignorance of moral perception
And style her power beyond her pride to quitquit: leave us.
Do they live still?
Yes, and make to harbor.
Most miserable men. I grieve their fortunes.
How happy had they been had the sea covered 'em!
They leap from one calamity to another.
Had they been drowned they had ended all their sorrows.
What shouts of joy they make!
Alas, poor wretches. Had they but once experience
Of this island they'd turn their tunes to wailings.
Nay, to curses
That ever they set foot on such calamities.
Here's nothing but rocks and barrenness—
Hunger, and cold to eat—here's no vineyards
To cheer the heart of man, no crystal rivers
After his labor to refresh his body;
If he be feeble, nothing to restore him
But heavenly hopes. Nature that made those remedies
Dares not come here nor look on our distresses
For fear she turn wild like the place, and barren.
Oh, uncle, yet a little memory of what we were!
'Twill be a little comfort in our calamities.
When we were seated in our blessèd homes,
How happy in our kindreds, in our families,
In all our fortunes!
Curse on those French pirates that displanteddisplanted: evicted, dislodged us,
That flung us from that happiness we found there,
ConstrainedConstrained: Forced, confined us to sea to save our lives, honors, and our riches
With all we had—our kinsmen and our jewels—
In hope to find some place free from such robbers,
Where a mighty storm severed our barksbarks: wooden ships,
That, where my wife, my daughter,
And my noble ladies that went with her—
Virgins and loving souls—to 'scape those pirates.
They are living yet; such goodness cannot perish.
But never to me, cousin,
Never to me again. What bears their flag-staves?What bears their flag-staves: i.e., what flag does their ship carry?
The arms of France, sure—
Nay, do not start; we cannot be more miserable.
Death is a cordialcordial: comforting or reviving medicine or beverage now, come when it will.
They get to shore apaceapace: quickly. They'll flyfly: flee as fast

When once they find the place. What's that which swims there?What's ... swims there?: "[T]here" might be accompanied by a gesture towards the audience. Actors would often gesture or look to the audience to create a sense of the imagined space of the sea or anything that is being referred to at a distance (Syme, 93-118).
A strong young man, sir, with a handsome woman
Hanging about his neck.
That shows some honor.
May thy bravebrave: fine, worthy charity, what e'er thou art,
Be spoken in a place that may renown thee
And not die here.
The boat it seems turned over—
So forced to their shiftsshifts: last extremities, great efforts—yet all are landed.
They're pirates, on my life.
They will not rob us
For none will take our misery for riches.
Come, cousin, let's descend and try their pities.
If we get off, a little hope walks with us,
If not, we shall but load this wretched island
With the same shadows still that must grow shorter.

div.stage: Enter Albert, Aminta, Tibalt, Morillat, Lamure, Franville, Master, Surgeon, and Sailors.

lg.l: Wet! Come ashore, my mates; we are safe arrived yet.
Thanks to heaven's goodness: no man lost!
The ship rides fair, too, and leaks in good plightgood plight: good condition.
The weather's turned more courteous. Albert turning to Aminta.
How does, my dearHow does my dear: i.e., How are you?? Alas, how weak she is and wet!
I am glad yet: I 'scaped with life;
Which certain, noble captainnoble: fine, good, next to heaven's goodness
I must thank you for; and which is more,
Acknowledge your dear tenderness, your firm love
To your unworthy mistress, and recant too
(Indeed, I must) those harsh opinions,
Those cruel, unkind thoughts, I heaped upon ye.
Farther than that, I must forget your injuries.
So far I am tied and fetteredfettered: bound with fetters or chains to your service,
Believe me I will learn to love.
I thank ye, madam;
And it shall be my practice to serve.
What cheerWhat cheer: i.e., How do you feel?, companions?
No great cheer, sir: a piece of sousedsoused: pickled biscuit
And half a hard egg, for the sea has taken orderorder: the sum total.
Being young and strong we shall not surfeitsurfeit: suffer from over indulgence in food or drink, captain.
For mine own part, I'll dance 'til I'm dry.
Come, Surgeon, out with your clyster-pipeclyster-pipe: tube used to insert medicine into the rectum
And strike a galliardgalliard: quick and lively dance.
What a bravebrave: fine, worthy day again,
And what fair weather after so foul a storm!
Ay! An't pleased the Master, he might ha' seen
This weather and ha' saved our goods—
Never think on 'em; we have saved our lives and healths.
I must think on 'em and think:
'Twas most maliciously done to undo me—
And me, too; I lost all.
I haven't another shirt to put upon me, nor clothes
But these poor rags. I had fifteen fair suits;
The worst was cut upon taffetytaffety: fine, crisp fabric of a plain weave.
I am glad you ha' lost. Give me thy hand—
Is this skin whole? Art thou not purledpurled: covered in purl stitches with scabs?
No ancient monuments of madam VenusVenus: Roman goddess of beauty and love?
Thou hast a suit, then, will posepose: confuse, perplex the cunning'st tailor
That will never turn fashion nor forsake thee
'Til thy executors, the worms, uncaseuncase: skin; also, undress thee;
They take off glorious suitssuits: suits of clothing; also, legal pursuits, Franville; thou art happy
Thou art delivered of 'em. Here are no brokers,
No alchemists to turn 'em into metal

Nor leathered captainsleathered captains: captains in military dress (Bourne). with ladies to adore 'em.Here are ... to adore 'em: Tibalt tries to defend Albert and the Captain's orders to discard the men's belongings for the safety of the crew. He challenges Franville by saying there is no one here to admire his suits, i.e. there are no people to impress with the fabrics they are made up of or how he looks while wearing them. Additionally, there is also no one there to buy his suits (i.e., to turn them into "metal," or coins). According to Tibalt, Franville's most important suit is his own body, specifically his skin.
Wilt thou see a dogfish rise in one of thy bravebrave: fine, worthy doubletsdoublets: close-fitting body-garments worn primarily by men
And tumble like a tub to make thee merry?
Or an old haddock rise with thy hatched swordhatched sword: light sword that can be used in one hand
Thou paid a hundred crownscrowns: British coins with a value of five shillings for?
A mermaid in a mantlemantle: robe or cloak of your worships?

Or a dolphin in your double ruff?I am ... double ruff: Tibalt's monologue acts as a social commentary and revolves around how much importance noblemen gave to their material possessions, to the point where they evaluated their virtues and characters based on material goods. He begins with comparing their skins to gifts from the goddess of beauty and love that would never go out of fashion or abandon them until their bodies decayed after death and were devoured by worms. The purpose of this monologue is to acquaint the audience (and readers) with how social hierarchy was determined by material possessions by having Tibalt satirize the social practice. He suggests that clothes depicting our accomplishments as individuals is just as ridiculous as fish appearing in the clothes that have now sunk to the bottom of the sea.
Ye are merry, but if I take it thus,
If I be foistedfoisted: cheated and jeeredjeered: mocked out of my goods—
Nor I, I vow thee,
Nor Master, nor mate; I see your cunning.
Oh, be not angry, gentlemen.
Yes, sir, we have reason
And some friends I can makeAnd some friends I can make: i.e. I can bring the others to my side.
What I did, gentlemen, was for the general safety.
If ye aim at me I am not so tame.
Pray, take my counsel, gallantsgallants: men of fashion or women attired beautifully.
Fight not 'til the Surgeon be well;
He's damnable seasick, and may spoil all.
Besides, he has lost his fiddlestickfiddlestick: small instrument or insignificant item and the best
BoxBox: Surgical cupping glass, or possibly lidded case for ointments of boar's grease. Why do you make such faces
And hand your swords?
Who would ye fight with, gentlemen?
Who has done ye wrong? For shame, be better tempered.
No sooner come to give thanks for our safeties
But we must raise new civil broilscivil broils: communal conflicts amongst us,
Inflame those angry powers to shower new vengeance.
What can we expect for these unmanly murmurs,
These strong temptations of their holy pietiesholy pieties: feelings of pity, devotion, and faithfulness,
But plagues in another kind, a fullera fuller: i.e. a more fully felt or accumulated plague so dreadful
That the singing storms are slumbers in it?
Be men, and rule your minds.
If you will needs fight, gentlemen,
And think to raise new riches by your valors,
Have at ye; I have little else to do now.
I have said my prayers. You say you have lost
And make your loss your quarrel,
And grumble at my captain here, and the Master,
Two worthy persons—indeed, too worthy for such rascals,
Thou galloongalloon: gaily dressed gallantgallant: man of fashion, and MammonMammon: demonic agent of avarice, you
That build on golden mountains thou money maggotmoney maggot: i.e., one who feeds off money and material possessions,
Come all, draw your swords! Ye say ye are miserable— Tibalt drawing sword.
Nay, hold, good Tibalt.
Captain, let me correct 'em!
I'll make ye ten times worse—I will not leave 'em—
For look ye: fighting is as nourishing to me as eating,
I was born quarrelling.
Pray, sir—
I will not leave 'em skins to cover 'em!
Do ye grumble when ye are well, ye rogues?
NobleNoble: Fine, good du-Pont—
Ye have clothes now and ye prateprate: cluck, howl, or chatter!
Pray, gentlemen, for my sake be at peace.
Let it become me to make all friends.
You have stopped our angers, lady.
This shows noblenoble: finely, splendidly—
'Tis well, 'tis very well. There's half a biscuit:
Break't amongst ye all, and thank my bountybounty: worth, virtue;
This is clothes and plateplate: gold or silver coin, too. Come, no quarrelling.
But ha! What things are these?
Are they human creatures?
I have heard of sea-calvessea-calves: seals.
They are no shadows, sure; they have legs and arms.
They hang but lightly on, though.
How they look; are they men's faces?
They have horsetails growing to 'em,
Goodly long manes.
Alas, what sunk eyes they have!
How they are crept in as if they had been frighted!
Sure they are wretched men.
Where are their wardrobes?
Look ye, Franville; here are a couple of courtiers.
They kneel. Alas, poor souls.
What are ye? Speak! Are ye alive
Or wandering shadows that find no peace on earth
'Til ye reveal some hidden secret?
We are men as you are,
Only our miseries make us seem monsters.
If ever pity dwelt in noble hearts—
We understand 'em, too. Pray, markmark: watch 'em, gentlemen.
Or that heaven is pleased with human charity,
If ever ye have heard the name of friendship
Or suffered in your selves the least afflictions,
Have gentle fathers that have bred ye tenderly
And mothers that have wept for your misfortunes,
Have mercy on our miseries!
Stand up, wretches.
Speak boldly and have release.
If ye be Christians
And by that blessed name bound to relieve us,
Convey us from this island.
Speak! What are ye?
As you are: gentle born. To tell ye more
Were but to number up our own calamities
And turn your eyes wild with perpetual weepings.

These many years in this most wretched islandThese many years: Despite being discovered by another crew Sebastian does not go into detail about how long he and Nicusa have been stranded on the island. Their physical state and appearance, such as "goodly long manes" and "sunk eyes," provide some clues, but these details are not enough to indicate an exact number of years. The unspecified number of years opens up interpretation not only to how long the men have been stranded, but how long they have been separated from the Portuguese women. We later learn that enough time has passed for Clarinda, who seems to have come to the island as a very small child, to grow to sexual maturity.
We two have lived. The scornscorn: object of contempt and game of FortuneFortune: Roman goddess of luck—
Bless yourselves from it, noblenoble: fine, good gentlemen—
The greatest plagues that human nature suffers
Are seated here: wildness, and wantswants: shortages innumerable.
How came ye hither?
In a ship, as you do, and (as you might have been
Had not heaven preserved ye for some more noblenoble: better, finer use)
Wrecked desperately, our men and all consumed
But we two that still live and spin out
The thin and ragged threads of our misfortunesThe thin ... misfortunes: from Greek mythology, referring to the threads of fate.
Is there no meat above?
Nor meat, nor quiet,
No summer here to promise anything
Nor autumn to make fullmake full: i.e. make more fully felt or accumulated the reaper's hands.
The earth, obdurateobdurate: resistant to influence, physically hard to the tears of heaven,
Lets nothing shootshoot: i.e., grow but poisoned weeds.
No rivers, nor no pleasant groves, no beasts;
All that were made for man's use flyfly: flee this desert.
No airy fowl dares make his flight over it
It is so ominous:

l.seg: Serpents and ugly things, the shames of nature,

lg.l: Roots of malignantmalignant: damaging or harmful tastes, foul standing waters.

l.seg: Sometimes we find a fulsomefulsome: difficult to digest sea-root
And that's a delicatedelicate: delicacy, a rat sometimes,
And that we hunt like princes in their pleasure.
And when we take a toad, we make a banquet

lg.l: For heaven's sake, let's aboard.
D'ye know no farther?
Yes, we have sometimes seen the shadow of a place inhabited
And heard the noise of hunters,
And we have attempted to find it. So far as a river—
Deep, slow, and dangerous, fenced with high rocks—
We have gone but, not able to achieve the hazardbut not able ... hazard: i.e. not able to cross the river,
Return to our old miseries.
If this sad story may deserve your pities—
Ye shall aboard with us; we will relieve your miseries.
Nor will we be unthankful for this benefit.
No, gentlemen, we'll pay for our deliverance. Sebastian gesturing towards heaps.
Look, ye that ploughplough: figuratively tilling fields, but in this case more generally a means of earning one's livelihood the seas for wealth and pleasures,
That outrun day and night with your ambitions,
Look on those heaps. They seem hard ragged quarriesquarries: reserves of stone;
Remove 'em and view 'em fully.
Oh heaven, they are gold and jewels!
Be not too hasty; here lies another heap.
And here another!
All perfect gold—
Stand farther off. You must not be your own carverscarvers: those who apportion or carve meat at table.
We have shares, and deep ones—
Yes, sir, we'll maintain't. Ho, fellow sailors!
Stand all to your freedoms;
I'll have all this—
And I this!
You shall be hanged, first!
My losses shall be made good!
So shall mine, or with my sword I'll do't.
All that shall share with us, assist us!
Captain, let's set in.
This money will undo us, undo us all.
This gold was the overthrow of my happiness.
I had command, too, when I landed here,
And led young, high, and noblenoble: fine, splendid spirits under me.
This cursed gold enticing 'em, they set upon their captain—
On me that owned this wealth, and this poor gentleman—
Gave us no few wounds, forced us from our own.
And then their civil swords, who should be owners
And who lords over all, turned against their own lives:
First, in their rage consumed the ship—
That poor part of the ship that 'scaped the first wreck—
Next, their lives by heaps. Oh, be you wise and careful!
We'll ha' more, sirrahsirrah: contemptuous address used to men and boys, come show it—
Or ten times worse afflictions than thou speak'st of!
Nay, and ye will be dogs.

div.stage: Exit Albert, driving off Lamure and Franville.

lg.l: Let me come, captain.

This golden age must have an iron ending.This golden age ... iron ending: reference to two of the five different ages of man from Greek mythology; the Golden Age was the first and best age. Iron refers to the last and worst age of mankind, signaling the transition of Albert's crew from a state of comfort and civility to a state of brutishness and toil. Tibalt draws his sword.
Have at the bunch!

div.stage: Exit Tibalt, driving off remaining French men.

lg.l: Oh, Albert! Oh, gentlemen! Oh, friends!
Come, noblenoble: fine, good nephew. If we stay here, we die.
Here rides their ship, yet all are gone to'th' spoilspoil: valuable goods, i.e. Sebastian and Nicusa's gold.
Let's make a quick use.
Away, dear uncle.
This gold was our overthrow—
It may now be our happiness!

div.stage: Enter Tibalt and Albert, in pursuit of the rest.

lg.l: You shall have gold, yes: I'll cram it in't' ye!
You shall be your own carverscarvers: those who apportion or carve meat at table, yes: I'll carvecarve: apportion or carve meat at table; here also referring to attacking with a sword ye!
I am sore; I pray, hear reason—
I'll hear none;
Covetous basebase: low-born, not noble minds have no reason.
I am hurt myself, but whilst I have a leg left
I will so haunt your gilded souls. How d'ye, captain?
Ye bleed apaceapace: quickly, curse on the causers on't;
D'ye not faint?
No, no, I am not so happy.
D'ye howl? Nay, ye deserve it,
BaseBase: Low-born, not noble greedy rogues. Come, shall we make an end of 'em?
They are our countrymen. For heaven's sake, spare 'em.
Alas, they are hurt enough and they relent now.
Oh captain, captain!
Whose voice is that?
The lady's.
Look captain, look! Ye are undone, poor captain,
We are all undone; all, all, we are all miserable!
Mad, willful men, ye are undone! Your ship! Your ship!
What of her?
She's under sail and floating.
See where she flies! See to your shames, you wretches!
Those poor starved things that showed you gold—
They have cut the cables
And got her out. The tide, too, has befriended 'em.
Where are the sailors that kept her?
Here, here in the mutiny to take up money,
And left no creature; left the boat ashore, too!

l.seg: This gold, this damned enticing gold!

lg.l: How the wind drives her,
As if it vied to force her from our furies!
Come back, good old men—
Good honest men, come back!
The wind's against ye; speak louder!
Ye shall have all your gold again! They see us—
Hold up your hands, and kneel,
And howl, ye blockheads; they'll have compassion on ye;
Yes, yes, 'tis very likely! Ye have deserved it.
D'ye look like dogs now?
Are your might courages abated?
I bleed apaceapace: quickly, Tibalt.
Retire, sir, and make the best use of our miseries;
They but begin now.
Are ye alive still?

div.stage: Exit Aminta, Lamure, Franville, and Sailors

lg.l: Yes, sweet.
Help him off, lady,
And wrap him warm in your arms—
Here's something that's comfortable—off with him handsomelyhandsomely: fittingly,
I'll come to ye straight, but vex these rascals a little.
Oh! I am hungry, and hurt, and I am weary.
Here's a pestlepestle: leg or haunch of an animal of a portagueportague: 16th century Portuguese gold coin, sir; Tibalt holding up gold.
'Tis excellent meat, with sour sauce.
And here's two chains; suppose them sausages.
Then there wantswants: lacks mustard,
But the fearful Surgeon will supply ye presently.
Oh for that Surgeon! I shall die else.
Faith, there he lies in the same picklepickle: an unpleasant situation, too.
My salvessalves: healing ointments for wounds or sores and all my instruments are lost.
And I am hurt and starved.
Good sir, seek for some herbs.
Here's herb gracelessherbs graceless: referring to herb-of-grace, another name for common rue; will that serve?
Gentlemen, will ye go to supper?
Where's the meat?
Where's the meat? What a veal voice is thereWhat a veal voice is there: Tibalt is comparing the question of the crew members to the bawling of calves.
Would we had it, sir, or anything else.
I would now cut your throat, you dog,
But that I would not do you such a courtesy
To take you from the benefit of starving.
Oh! What a comfort will your worship have, some three days hence!
Yea, things beneath pity shall be your harbingerharbinger: one who provides lodgings, a host.
You must not look for down-beds here,
Nor hangingshangings: curtains, though I could wish ye strong onesstrong ones: i.e. strong halters for hanging and providing quick death (Bourne).

Yet here be many lightsomelightsome: graceful, elegant, cool, star-chambersstar-chambers: the open air; also, a reference to the English court established in the 15th century to try socially and politically important defendants—
Open to every sweet air, I'll assure ye—
Ready provided for ye. And so I'll leave ye:
Your first course is served; expect the second.
A vengeance on these jewels.
Oh! This cursed gold!
Alas, dear soul, ye faint.
You speak the language
Which I should use to you. Heaven knows, my weakness
Is not for what I suffer in myself,
But to imagine what you endure and to what fate
Your cruel stars reserve ye.
Do not add to my afflictions
By your tender pities. Sure, we have changed sexes:
You bear calamity with a fortitude
Would become a man; I, like a weak girl, suffer.
Oh, but your wounds,
How fearfully they gape! And every one
To me is a sepulchersepulcher: tomb or burial place. If I loved truly—
Wise men affirm that true love can do wonders—
This, bathed in my warm tears, would soon be cured
And leave no orifice behind. Pray give me leave
To play the Surgeon and bind 'em up,
The raw air ranklesrankles: festers, esp. to a degree that causes pain 'em.
Sweet, we wantwant: lack means.
Love can supply all wantswants: shortages.
What have ye done, sweet?
Oh sacrilege to beauty! There's no hair
Of these pure locks by which the greatest king
Would not be gladly bound and love his fettersfetters: binds, chains.
Oh Albert! I offer this sacrifice of service

To the altar of your staid temperance and still adore it.This moment depicts a sacrifice of body for body with clear religious connotations playing on the world "altar" (as she alters her own body to save his).
When with a violent hand you made me yours
I cursed the doer, but now I consider:
How long I was in your power! And with what honor
You entertained me! It being seldom seen
That youth and heat of blood could e'er prescribe
Laws to itself, your goodness is the LetheLethe: from Greek mythology, referring to a river in Hades that causes forgetfulness
In which I drown your injuries, and now I live
Truly to serve ye. How do you, sir?
Receive you the least from my service?
If you do, I am largely recompensed.recompensed: repaid
You good angels
That are engaged when man's ability fails
To reward goodness, look upon this lady.
Though hunger grips my croaking entrails, Albert kissing Aminta.
Yet when I kiss these rubiesrubies: i.e., Aminta's lips methinks
I'm at a banquet, a refreshing banquet.
Speak my blessèd one, art not hungry?
Indeed I could eat, to bear your company.

Blush, unkind Natureunkind Nature: this phrasing suggests Albert blames Nature (here, personified) for putting him and Aminta into this harsh environment. To bolster his point, he provides two examples of Nature's unfair treatment of them: the first one is that nature gives a "drunkard" more wine, and a "glutton" more food, though the drunkard has already drunk and has no need for more wine, and the glutton already has enough food. Thus, Albert attempts to shame Nature into providing aid to her more deserving victims, especially Aminta (a "virgin" who is "pin[ing] for hunger").,
If thou hast power or being to hear
Thyself and by such innocence accused
Must print a thousand kinds of shames upon
Thy various face, can'st thou supply a drunkard—
And with a prodigal hand reach choice of wines
'Til he cast upcast up: vomit thy blessings—or a glutton—
That robs the elements to sooth his palate
And only eats to beget appetite,
Not to be satisfied—and suffer here
A virgin—which the saints would make their guest—
To pinepine: starve or waste away for hunger? Sounding of horns.
Ha! If my sense
Deceive me not, these notes take being
From the breath of men. Confirm me, my Aminta—
Again this way the gentle wind conveys it to us—
Hear you nothing?

Yes, it seems free hunters' music.In this scene, Albert hears the music from the Amazonian island that would have influences from Portugal, and possibly its colonies in the Middle East and West India. The play is written in the midst of colonial dominion in Europe, indicated by how it mimics The Tempest. It is possible some of the common music instruments possessed by the Portuguese (or what was imagined to be possessed by them) can be showcased on stage. One possible sound that can be recreated on stage is of the adufe, a square double-skinned frame drum. The skins are sewn together, often with seeds between them; it is held with the thumbs of both hands and the pointer of the right hand, leaving the other fingers free to hit the instrument. This instrument was introduced into Portugal (and Spain) when the Moors of North Africa invaded the Iberian Peninsula, beginning in the early 700s A.D. As the music is also accompanied by the adjective "hunter's," Fletcher and Massinger may be referring to these 'exotic' (i.e. tribal) instruments from North Africa.
Still 'tis louder! And I remember the Portugals
Informed us they had often heard such sounds
But ne'er could touch the shore from whencewhence: where it came.
Follow me, my Aminta! My good genius,
Show me the way still!
Still we are directed!
When we gain the top of this near rising hill
We shall know further.
Courteous ZephyrusZephyrus: Greek god of the west wind
On his dewy wings carries perfumes to cheer us—
The air clears too—
And now we may discerndiscern: perceive, recognize another island
And, questionless, the seat of fortunate men.
Oh that we could arrive there!
No, Albert, 'tis not to be hoped.
This envious torrent's cruelly interposedinterposed: placed between.
We have no vessel that may transport us
Nor hath nature given us wings to fly.
Better try all hazardshazards: risks of loss or harm, dangers
Than perish here remediless! I feel
New vigor in me, and a spirit that dares
More than a man to serve my fairAminta.
These arms shall be my oars with which I'll swim,
And my zeal to save thy innocent self
Like wings shall bear me up above the brackish waves.
Will ye then leave me?
'Til now I ne'er was wretched.
My best Aminta, I swear by goodness
'Tis nor hope, nor fear of myself, that invites me
To this extreme; 'tis to supply thy wantswants: shortages. And believe me,
Though pleasure met me in most ravishingravishing: exciting pleasure or ecstasy forms
And happiness courted me to entertain her,
I would nor eat nor sleep 'til I returned
And crowned thee with my fortunes.
Oh but your absence—!
Suppose it but a dream and, as you may,
Endeavor to take rest; and when that sleep
Deceives your hunger with imagined food,
Think you have sent me for discovery
Of some most fortunate continent yet unknown
Which you are to be queen of.
And now, ye powers that e'er heard lovers' prayers
Or cherished pure affection, look on him
That is your votaryvotary: one bound or devoted to worship or a particular vow and make it known,
Against all stops, you can defend your own.
How did we lose Clarinda?
When we believed the stag was spentspent: used up, worn out and would take soil,
The sight of the black lake, which we supposed
He chose for his last refuge, frighted him more
Than we that did pursue him.
That's usual, for death itself is not so terrible
To any beast of chasebeast of chase: i.e., animal being hunted.
Since we lived here, we ne'er could force one to it.
'Tis so dreadful
Birds, that with their pinions cleave the air,
Dare not fly over it. When the stag turned head
And we even tired with labor, Clarinda, as if
She were made of air and fire
And had no part of earth in her, eagerly pursued him.
Nor need we fear her safety; this place yields not
Fawns and satyrs or more lustfullustful: desirous of sexual satisfaction men.
Here we live secure,
And have among ourselves a commonwealthcommonwealth: political body in which every member has a voice or vested interest

Which, in ourselves begun, with us must end.with us must end: As the commonwealth's rules forbid any contact with the opposite sex (thus ruling out any forms of reproduction), these same rules will lead to the ultimate demise of the women and, with them, the commonwealth itself.
Ay, there's the misery.
But, being alone,
Allow me freedom but to speak my thoughts:
The strictness of our governess that forbids us
On pain of death the sight and use of men
Is more than tyranny. For herself, she's past
Those youthful heats and feels not the wantwant: lack
Of that which young maids long for. And her daughter,
The fair Clarinda, though in years
Improved in height and large proportion,
Came here so young
That, scarce remembering that she had a father,
She never dreams of man, and should she see one
In my opinion a'would appear a strange beast to her.
'Tis not so with us.
For my part I confess it: I was not made
For this single life, nor do I love hunting so
But that I had rather be the chase myself.
By VenusVenus: Roman goddess of beauty and love (out upon me, I should have sworn
By DianaDiana: Roman goddess of hunting and virginity), I am of thy mind too, wench!
And though I have ta'en an oath not alone
To detest but never to think of man,
Every hour something tells me I am forsworn,
For I confess imagination helps me sometimes
And that's all is left for us to feed on;
We might starve, else. For if I have any pleasure
In this life, but when I sleep I am a paganpagan: non-Christian, thought also at this time to be savage and uncivilized;
Then from the courtier to the country clown,
I have strange visionsvisions: i.e. dreams.
Visions, Crocale?
Yes, and fine visions, too,
And visions I hope in dreams are harmless

And not forbid by our canonscanons: rules, laws, or decrees, usually ecclesiasticalcanons: This word choice goes hand in hand with the ongoing theme of faith and religion throughout this play. The impurity or disobedience of canons not only breaks the commonwealth law but also can be seen as a type of sin.. The last night
(Truth, 'tis a foolish one, but I must tell it)
As I lay in my cabin betwixt sleeping and waking—
Upon your back?
How should a young maid lie, fool,
When she would be entranced?
We are instructed. Forward, I prithee.
Methought a sweet young man—
In years some twenty, with a downy chin
Promising a future beard, and yet no red one—
Stole slyly to my cabin all unbraced,
Took me in his arms, and kissed me twenty times!
Yet still I slept—
FieFie: exclamation inciting shame, usually said to children! Thy lips run over, Crocale!
But to the rest—
Lord, what a man is this, thought I,
To do this to a maid!
Yet then, for my life I could not wake.
The youth, a little daunted, with a trembling hand
Heaved up the clothes—
Yet still you slept—
I'faith I did! And when methoughts he was warm by my side,
Thinking to catch him, I stretched out both mine arms,
And when I felt him not, I shrieked out
And waked for anger!
'Twas a pretty dream.
Ay, if it had been a true one!
But staystay: wait, what's here cast o'th' shore?
'Tis a man!
Shall I shoot him?
No, no, 'tis a handsome beast!
Would we had more o'the breed. Stand close, wenches,
And let's hear if he can speak.
Do I yet live?
Sure it is air I breath. What place is this?
Sure something more than humanmore than human: i.e. divine or supernatural keeps residence here,
For I have passed the StygianStygian: from Greek mythology, referring to the river Styx gulph
And touch upon the blessed shore! 'Tis so:
This is the ElysianElysian: from Greek mythology, referring to Elysium, the heavenly paradise for fallen Greek heroes shade. These happy spirits
That here enjoy all pleasures—
He makes toward usHe makes toward us: i.e. He approaches us.
Stand, or I'll shoot!
Hold, he makes no resistance.
Be not offended, goddesses, that I fall
Thus prostrate at your feet; or if not suchif not such: i.e. if you are not goddesses,

But nymphs of Dian'sDian: Roman goddess of hunting and virginity trainNymphs of Dian's train: The combined effect of the references to Elysium, Styx, and Diana show a shift from Albert's presumably French Catholic faith to a classical mythological frame of mind. that range these groves
Which you forbid to men, vouchsafevouchsafe: acknowledge or bestow in some favorable manner to know
I am a man, a wicked sinful man, and yet not sold
So far to impudence as to presume
To press upon your privaciespress upon your privacies: i.e. intrude upon, importune or provoke
Your heavenly angers. 'Tis not for myself
I beg thus poorly, for I am already wounded,
Wounded to death, and faint. My last breath
Is for a virgin comes as near yourselves
In all perfectioncomes as ... perfection: i.e., Aminta's beauty approaches that of the commonwealth women as what's mortal may
Resemble things divine. Oh, pity her
And let your charity free her from that desert
If heavenly charity can reach to hell—
For sure that place comes near it—and where'er
My ghost shall find abode,
Eternally I shall pour blessings on ye.
By my life I can not hurt him.
Though I lose my head for it, nor I.
I must pity him, and will.
But staystay: stop! Clarinda—
What new gamegame: hunted animal have ye found here? Ha!
What beast is this lies wallowing in his gore?
Keep off—
Wherefore, I pray? I ne'er turned
From a fellfell: intensely destructive, dreadful lioness robbed of her whelpswhelps: in this case, lion cubs,
And shall I fear dead carrioncarrion: dead body, putrefying flesh?
O but—
But what is't?
It is infectious.
Has it not a name?
Yes, but such a name from which
As from the devil your mother commands us fly.Yes, but ... us fly: Crocale is referring to the command from Rosella that all commonwealth women flee from men
Is it a man?
It is.
What a bravebrave: fine, worthy shape it has in death.
How excellent would it appear had it life!
Why should it be infectious? I have heard
My mother say I had a father;
And was not he a man?
Questionless, madam.
Your fathers, too, were men?
Without doubt, lady.
And without such, it is impossible
We could have been.
A sin against nature to deny it.
Nor can you or I have any hope to be a mother
Without the help of men.
Impossible.
Which of you, then, most barbarous that knew
You from a man had being and owe to it
The name of parent, durstdurst: archaic past tense of dare presume to kill
The likeness of that thing by which you are?
Whose arrows made these wounds? Speak, or by DianDian: goddess of hunting and virginity
without distinction, I'll let flylet fly: shoot arrows at ye all!
Not mine.
Nor mine.
('Tis strange to see her moved thus.)
Restrain your fury, madam! Had we killed him
We had but performed your mother's command.
But if she command unjust and cruel things,
We are not to obey it.
We are innocent. Some storm did cast
Him shipwrecked on the shore as you see, wounded,
Nor durstdurst: archaic past tense of dare we be surgeons to such
Your mother doth appoint for death.
Weak excuse; where's pity?
Where's soft compassion? Cruel and ungrateful!
Did providenceprovidence: divine guidance offer to your charity
But one poor subject to express it on—
And in't to show our wantswants: shortages too—and could you
So carelessly neglect it?
For aughtaught: all I know, he's living yet,
And you may tempt your mother by giving him succorsuccor: help, aid, or assistance.
Ha! Come near, I chargecharge: order ye.
So, bend his body softly, rub his temples—
Nay, that shall be my officeoffice: duty or service. How the red
Steals into his pale lips! Run and fetch the simplessimples: medicines containing a single active ingredient, derived directly from nature without human intervention
With which my mother held my arm
When last I was wounded by the boar.
Do, but remember herremember her: i.e. remind or request her to come after ye
That she may behold her daughter's charity.
Now he breathes—

The air passing through the Arabian grovesArabian groves: Though the phrase "Arabian groves" is vague, it could suggest the increased cross-pollination of horticulture between Europe and the Middle East and India. Portugal had colonized several territories (Bahrain, Sohar, Julfar, Quriyat), now constituting modern-day Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, during the reign of the Iberian Union between 1580-1640 (de Oliveira Marques, 322). The Amazons are also believed to have originated in Libya and to have migrated across Syria, Egypt, Scythia (Foreman). The Arabian groves reference could refer to the coconut and palm trees that were commonly seen on the coast of Southwest India. After the conquests of Vasco Da Gama, Portugal colonized territories like Bombay and Goa by the Arabian Sea before India's major colonization by the British in the late seventeenth century (Narayanan, 198). It is therefore possible for Indian horticultural features to appear in an imagined Portuguese aesthetic.
Yields not so sweet an odor! Prithee, taste it,
Taste it good Crocale, yet I envy thee so great a blessing.
'Tis not sin to touch these rubies, is it?
Not, I think—

Or thus to live chameleon-likechameleon-like: Perhaps a reference to the chameleon's ability to blend into its surroundings, i.e., Clarinda will need to render her desire for Albert invisible because of the commonwealth's law against interacting with men. More likely, though, this refers to the belief that chameleons survived solely on air since Clarinda has been referring to Albert's breath. See William Shakespeare's The Two Gentlemen of Verona, where chameleons are referenced twice as both air-eaters and color-changers.
I could resign my essence to live ever thus.
Oh, welcome! Raise him up gently. Some soft hand
Bound up these wounds; a woman's hair. What fury
For which my ignorance does not know a name
Is crept into my bosom? But I forget Enter Hippolita with medicine.
My piouspious: pitiful, devoted, faithful work. Now, if this juicejuice: i.e., the medicine referenced earlier hath power,
Let it appear. His eyelids ope': prodigiousprodigious: astonishing, amazing!
Two suns breakbreak: burst forth from these orbs!
Ha! Where am I? What new vision's this?
To what goddess do I owe this second life?
Sure thou art more than mortal,
And any sacrifice of thanks or duty
In poor and wretched man to pay comes short
Of your immortal bountybounty: worth, virtue. But to show
I am not unthankful, thus in humility
I kiss the happy ground you have made sacred
By bearing of your weight.
No goddess, friend, but made
Of that same brittle mold as you are,
One too acquainted with calamities
And, from that, apt to pity. Charity ever
Finds in the act reward, and needs not trumpet
In the receiverCharity ever ... receiver: i.e. Kind acts are their own reward and do not require praise. Oh, forbearforbear: abstain from this duty!
I have a hand to meet with yours
And lips to bid yours welcome.
I see that, by instinct,
Though a young maid hath never seen a man,
Touches have titillations and inform herThough ... inform her: i.e. Though Clarinda has never met a man, instinctually she knows about sexual attraction.. Enter Rosella.
But here's our governess;
Now I expect a storm.
Child of my flesh
And not of my fair unspottedunspotted: unblemished mind,
Unhand this monster!
Monster, mother?
Yes, and every word he speaks, a siren's note

To drown the careless hearersiren's note ... hearer: Rosella likens Albert to the figure of the siren to reinforce her argument that men are dangerously manipulative. Based in Greek mythology, "sirens" were creatures that were part-women, part-bird or mermaid. They would lure sailors to destruction by enchanting them with song. Sirens have been traditionally gendered as women, but Rosella inverts this association, emphasizing Albert's manipulation. This linguistic inversion points to the larger theme of reversing traditional gender roles within play. Have I not taught thee
The falsehood and the perjuries of men
On whom but for a woman to show pity
Is to be cruel to herself? The sovereigntysovereignty: supreme power or domination
Proud and imperiousimperious: domineering men usurpusurp: inflict wrongfully upon us
We conferconfer: grant or agree to on ourselves, and love those fettersfetters: binds, chains
We fasten to our freedoms. Have we, Clarinda,
Since thy father's wreck, sought liberty
To lose it uncompelleduncompelled: without force? Did fortune guide—
Or rather, destiny—our barkbark: wooden ship, to which
We could appoint no portappoint no port: find no safe harbor, to this blessed place
Inhabited heretoforeheretofore: before now by warlike women
That kept men in subjection? Did we then,
By their example, after we had lost
All we could love in man, here plant ourselves
With execrableexecrable: awful, cursed oaths never to look
On man but as a monster? And wilt thou
Be the first precedentprecedent: instance establishing rule or guide to infringeinfringe: breach, violate those vows
We made to heaven?
Hear me, and hear with justice,
And as ye are delighted in the name
Of mother, hear a daughter that would be like you:
Should all women useuse: in this case, maintain, adhere to this obstinate abstinence
You would force upon us, in a few years
The whole world would be peopled
Only with beasts.
We must and will have men.
Ay, or we'll shake off all obedience.
Are ye mad?
Can no persuasion alter ye? Suppose
You had my suffragesuffrage: support, often in a spiritual or ecclesiastical sense to your suitsuit: legal pursuit:
Can this shipwrecked wretch supply them all?Can this ... all?: i.e., Can this single man provide all the commonwealth women with children
Hear me, great lady!
I have fellows in my misery not far hence.
DividedDivided: Separated [from us] only by this hellish river,
There live a company of wretched men
Such as your charity may make your slaves.
Imagine all the miseries mankind
May suffer under, and they groan beneath 'em.
But are they like to you?
Speak they your language?
Are they able, lustylusty: vigorous men?
They were, good ladies,
And in their May of youth, of gentle bloodof gentle blood: nobleborn; also, of gentle manners
And such as may deserve ye. Now cold and hunger
Hath lessened their perfection, but restored
To what they were I doubt not they'll appear
Worthy of your favors.
This is a blessing
We durstdurst: archaic past tense of dare not hope for.
Dear mother, be not obdurateobdurate: resistant to influence, physically hard.
Hear then my resolution, and labor not
To add to what I'll grantgrant: consent to, for 'twill be fruitless:
You shall appear as good angels to these wretched men.
In a small boat we'll pass o'er to 'em
And bring 'em comfort. If you like their persons,
And they approve of yours—for we'll force nothing—
And since we wantwant: lackceremoniesceremonies: religious engagements,
Each one shall choose a husband and enjoy
His company a month, but that expired
You shall no more come near 'em. If you prove fruitfulIf you prove fruitful: i.e., If you become pregnant,
The males ye shall return to them, the females

We will reserve ourselvesThe males ... reserve ourselves: Rosella's command is that any boys born by the commonwealth women will be given to the men, while any girls will stay with the women and become part of the commonwealth. The Amazons were supposedly neighbors to an all-male society called the Gargareans. They met annually for a mating ritual. The female children born after this ritual were retained by the Amazons, and the male children went to their fathers (Strabo). Rosella's reference to this practice of mating with an all-male society had historical precedent. It also provides some geographical hints. As the Gargareans and Amazons are believed to have reigned between Eurasia and the Middle East, the play hints at taking place in the Mediterranean or Black Sea. (Indeed, the play references a black river between the barren and fertile islands.) This is the utmost
Ye shall e'er obtain. As ye think fit,
Ye may dismiss this stranger
And prepare tomorrow for the journey.
Come, sir, will ye walk?
We will show ye our pleasant bowersbowers: natural dwellings, habitations, or abodes typically used for amorous meetings
And something ye shall find to cheer your heart.
Excellent lady,
Though 'twill appear a wonder one near starved
Should refuse rest and meat, I must not take
Your noblenoble: fine, splendid offer. I left in yonder desert
A virgin almost pinedpined: starved or wasted—
She's not your wife?
No, lady, but my sister ('tis now dangerous
To speak truth). To her I deeply vowed
Not to taste food or rest if Fortune brought it me,
'Til I blessed her with my return. Now, if you please
To affordafford: allow, provide me an easy passage to her
And some meat for her recovery,
I shall live your slave, and thankfully
She shall ever acknowledge her life at your service.
You plead so well I can deny ye nothing.
I myself will see you furnishedfurnished: provided,
And with the next sun visit and relieve thee.

Ye are all goodness—Ye are all goodness—: The long dash closing this act (present in the 1647 folio text) adds a level of ambiguity to the exit. Later instances of long dashes in the 1647 folio are used to indicate interruptions in the dialogue. Therefore, we could assume that Albert is being interrupted at the closing of the scene, though the text does not give indication of exactly what or who could be interrupting Albert. The long dash could allow actors to vary the portrayal of this end scene. One implication could be that Albert and Clarinda walk out of the stage with redundant pleasantries, formalities, and exchanges that the authors and printers did not deem worthy of consuming the page's highly sought-for space. Another implication could be that the next scene immediately follows as they exit. The dash could also represent space on the page, indicating that more words were spoken here, up to the actors' or the company's discretion or improvisation.
Oh, what a tempest have I in my stomach!
How my empty guts cry out! My wounds ache;
Would they but bleed again that I might get
Something to quench my thirst.
Oh, Lamure, the happiness my dogs had
When I kept house at home! They had a storehouse,
A storehouse of most blessed bones and crusts,
Happy crusts! Oh! How sharp hunger pinches me!
Oh my importunateimportunate: persistently troublesome, urgent belly, I have nothing
To satisfy thee. I have sought
As far as my weak legs would carry me
Yet can find nothing, neither meat nor water,
Nor anything that's nourishing.
My belly's grown together like an empty satchel.

div.stage: Enter Franville holding rocks, mud, and other debris.

lg.l: How now, what news?
Hast any meat yet?
Not a bit that I can see.
Here be goodly quarriesquarries: reserves of stone, but they be cruel hard
To gnaw. I ha' got some mud—we'll eat it with spoons—
Very good thick mud, but it stinks damnably.
There's old rotten trunks of trees, too,
But not a leaf nor blossom in all the island.
How it looks—!
It stinks too.
It may be poison—
Let it be anything
So I can get it down. Why, man,

Poison's a princely dish.Poison's a princely dish: A possible version of the idiom: "one man's poison is another man's meat," essentially meaning "people have different tastes" or "value is relative." The idiom was used by Beaumont and Fletcher's contemporary Thomas Middleton in his 1604 work Plato's Cap ("That old moth-eaten proverb... One man's meat, is another man's poison"), though also by Beaumont himself in Love's Cure, which was also published for the first time in the 1647 folio: "What's one man's poison, Signor, is another's meat or drink." In a literal way, the palates of the shipwrecked nobles must shift from meat to mud ("poison"). At the same time, it may suggest that societal rules/morality is also relative: one man's good behavior (meat) is another one's bad (poison) and vice versa. But in the context of the shipwreck, "poison" suggests a kind of moral suspension: the behavior that was once deemed bad in society is no longer considered bad on the island.
Hast thou no biscuit?
No crumbs left in thy pocket? Here's my doubletdoublet: close-fitting body-garment worn primarily by men:
Give me but three small crumbs.
Not for three kingdoms,
If I were master of 'em. Oh, Lamure,
But one poor joint of muttonjoint of mutton: portion of meat from an adult sheep, often considered less palatable than other meats—we have scornedscorned: acted contemptuously, man—
Thou speakest of paradise—
Or but the snuffs of those healthssnuffs of those healths: dregs of drinks
We have lewdlylewdly: ignorantly, foolishly at midnight flung away!
Ah! But to lick the glasses!
Here comes the Surgeon. What
Hast thou discovered? Smile, smile and comfort us.
I am expiring;
Smile, they that can. I can find nothing, gentlemen;
Here's nothing can be meat without a miracle.
Oh, that I had my boxesboxes: surgical cupping glasses, or possibly lidded cases for ointments and lintslints: soft materials used for dressing wounds now,

My stupesstupes: medicinal pieces of cloths used on wounds, my tentstents: rolls of soft, absorbent material, which were often medicated and used to stop wounds from bleeding, and those sweet helps of nature;
What dainty dishes could I make of 'em.
Hast nearHast near: Do you have nearby an old suppositorysuppository: medicine administered through a bodily orifice, usually the rectum—?
Oh, would I had, sir.
Or but the paper where such a cordialcordial: comforting or reviving medicine or beverage,
Potion, or pills hath been entombed—

Or the blessed bladderbladder: prepared bladder of an animal, inflated and used as a receptacle for lard or other substances where a cooling clystercooling clyster: plant-based medicine used for soothing fevers—
Hast thou no cereclothscerecloths: surgical plasters left?
Nor any old poulticepoultice: substance applied to the skin as part of a bandage—?
We care not to what it hath been ministeredministered: applied—
Sure I have none of these daintiesdainties: delicacies, gentlemen.
Where's the great wenwen: wart, cyst, tumor, or other protuberance of the body
Thou cut'st from Hugh the sailor's shoulder?
That would serve now for a most princely banquet.
Ay, if we had it, gentlemen.
I flung it overboard, slave that I was—
A most unprovident villain!
If I had anything that were but supple now,
I could make salads of your shoes, gentlemen,
And rare ones; anything unctuousunctuous: meaty, greasy!
Ay, and then we might fry the soles i'th' sun;
The soles would make a second dish—
Or sousesouse: brine, pickle 'em in the saltwater;
An inner sole well sousedsoused: pickled—
Here comes the woman.
It may be she has meat and may relieve us.
Let's withdraw, and markmark: keep watch, and then be ready;
She'll hide her storestore: collection of goods, in this case, food, else, and so cozencozen: deceive or dupe us.
How weary and how hungry am I;
How feeble and how faint is all my body.
Mine eyes, like spentspent: used up, worn out lamps glowing out, grow heavy;
My sight forsaking me, and all my spirits,
As if they heard my passing bellpassing bell: proverbially, death knell go for me,
Pull in their powers and give me up to destiny.
Oh! For a little water, a little, little meat,
A little to relieve me ereere: before I perish.
I had whole floods of tears awhile that nourished me,
But they are all consumed for thee, dear Albert;
For thee they are spentspent: used up, worn out, for thou art dead;
Merciless fate hath swallowed thee.
Oh, I grow heavy; sleep is a salvesalve: healing ointment for wounds or sores for misery.
Heaven, look on me and either take my life
Or make me once more happy.
She's fast asleep already!
Why should she have this blessing and we wake still,
Wake to our wantswants: shortages?
This thing hath been our overthrow,
And all these biting mischiefs that fall on us
Are come through her means.
True we were bound—ye all know—
For happy places and most fertile islands
Where we had constant promises of all things.
She turned the captain's mind
And must have him go in search, I know not of who,
Nor to what end—of such a fool, her brother,

And such a coxcombcoxcomb: a foolish person, or a vain man, her kinsmansuch a coxcomb, her kinsman: "coxcomb" primarily refers to a rooster's crest, or a "cock's comb." Given that jester hats resemble roosters' crests, and jesters are fools, the word "coxcomb" evolved to describe not only the jester's cap but fools themselves. The word "coxcomb" can also describe a vain, pretentious, and foppish person, perhaps because roosters are viewed as prideful. In other words, someone described as a coxcomb pretends to be stylish and educated. As jesters are the noble's personal comedians and storytellers, Franville's use takes on additional meaning. The insult could imply that Aminta's relative is pseudo-nobility who amuses other nobles with attempts at legitimacy. Given that the men believe it is okay for superiors eat their inferiors, Franville's disqualification of Aminta's family may also justify his turn to cannibalism.—
And we must put input in: make harbor everywhere;
She has put us in now, i'faith.
Why should we consumeconsume: waste away thus and starve—
Have nothing to relieve us—
And she live there that bred all our miseries,
Unroasted or unsodunsod: unboiled, uncooked?
I have read in stories—
Of such restoring meats
We have examples,

Thousand examples and allowed for excellentThousand examples ... excellent: Discourse on cannibalism in the early modern period became more prevalent following European contact with real and imagined cannibals in North and South America. Cannibalism in the Americas was largely reviled by Europeans. However, during the period this play was written there was also a medicinal cannibalistic culture thriving throughout Europe. The medicinal discourse between Lamure, Morrilat, Franville, and the Surgeon earlier in the play are relevant to this discussion in that they consider eating a "wen" that was pulled from one of the sailor's shoulders during the voyage. Prior to this, the group primarily discusses tools of medicine; the brief mention of "cordials," "potions," and "pills" takes on a different meaning due to many medications being made from human parts, with some of the most common sources being blood and bone (Sugg).:
Women that have eat their children,
Men their slaves—nay their brothers—but these are nothing!
Husbands devoured their wives (they are their chattelschattels: possessions, goods, often with relation to livestock),
And of a schoolmaster that, in time of famine,
Powdered upPowdered up: Seasoned with salt or pickled all his scholars.
She's young and tidytidy: healthy.
In my conscience, she'll eat delicately
Just like young pork; a little lean.
Your opinion, Surgeon.
I think she may be made good meat.
But look, we shall wantwant: lack salt.
TushTush: contemptuous, impatient exclamation, she needs no powderingpowdering: salt seasoning.
I grant ye;

But to suck out the humorous partssuck out the humorous parts: In pre-modern physiology, the humors were four different fluids in the body; when imbalanced, one's body and mood risked falling out of health and displaying the symptoms respective to the type of imbalance. The word "humorous" is also used to mean moody or capricious. Being a doctor (and thus knowledgeable of the humors), the Surgeon wishes to remove them from Aminta's body before the men eat her. Yet the act of removing her humors is telling. In one way, he expresses concern for his health by emptying the humors: if he were to eat Aminta's humors, he could contract an imbalance—whether an excess or a deficit—of his own humors. At the same time, Aminta is female and so stereotyped in early modern drama as capricious and changeable. This could suggest the Surgeon fears he could contract her emotionality over his "balanced" male rationality if he were to eat her. This line could also be read, more simply, as an indication of the Surgeon's desire to eat the humorous (i.e. "juicy") parts of her body.— by all means
Let's kill her in a chase, she'll eat the sweeter.
Let's kill her any way, and kill her quickly
That we might be at our meat.
How if the captain—
Talk not of him! He's dead, and the rest famished.
Wake her, Surgeon, and cut her throat;
And then divide her, every man his share—
She wakes herself.
Holy and good things keep me!
What cruel dreams have I had. Who are these?
Oh, they are my friends. For heaven's sake, gentlemen,
Give me some food to save my life, if ye have aughtaught: anything to spare;
A little to relieve me. I may bless ye,
For weak and wretched, ready to perish,
Even now I die.
You'll save a labor, then.
You bred these miseries and you shall pay for't.
We have no meat, nor where to have we know not,
Nor how to pull ourselves from these afflictions.
We are starved, too, famished; all our hopes deludeddeluded: deceived.
Yet ereere: before we die thus, we'll have one dainty meal.
Shall I be with ye, gentlemen?
Yes, marrymarry: expression of surprise used to emphasize what follows shall ye; in our bellies, lady.
We love you well—
What said you, sir?
MarryMarry: expression of surprise used to emphasize what follows, we'll eat your ladyship—
You that have buried us in this basebase: of low quality or worth island;
We'll bury ye in a more noblenoble: fine, splendid monuments.
Will ye say your prayers that I may perform, lady?
We are wonderous sharp-setsharp-set: acutely hungry. Come, gentlemen,
Who are for the hinderhinder: rear parts?
I—
And I!
Be patient;
They will not fall to every man's share.
Oh hear me,
Hear me, ye barbarous men—!
Be short and pithypithy: full of concentrated meaning,
Our stomachs cannot staystay: abide a long discourse—
And be not fearful,
For I'll kill ye daintily—
Are ye not Christians?
Why, do not Christians eat women?
Eat one another? 'Tis most impiousimpious: not pitiful, devoted, or faithful.
Come, come—
Oh! Help! Help! Help!
The lady's voice! Stand off, slaves!
What do you intend, villains?
I have strength enough left me, if you abuse this soul,
To—
They would have ravished her, upon my life!
Speak, how was it, lady?
Forgive 'em, 'twas their hungers—
Ha, their hungers!
They would have eaten her.
Oh, damned villains! Speak, is it true?
I confess an appetite.
An appetite? I'll fit ye for an appetite!

Are ye so sharp-set sharp-set: The use of "sharp-set" in this passage is layered. As an adjective, it describes a strong hunger (OED). However, it is also a word used to describe hawks, hounds, and other hunting animals and their eagerness for predatory behavior. That said, this use of "sharp-set" figures the shipwrecked nobles as savage beasts. Yet another definition of "sharp-set" is "having a craving for sexual indulgence," which also promotes the connection between food and sexual craving that appears throughout the passage. For example, with the first use of sharp-set, the men argue over who gets to eat her buttocks, and with the second use, Tibalt asks if the men are so hungry that Aminta's "flesh" must "serve" them, here again evoking sexual indulgence. As Aminta is the only woman on the barren island, it is worth noting that the cannibalism directed towards her—i.e., to consume her—is meant to be read as a sexual metaphor. that her flesh must serve you?
Murder's a mainmain: powerful good service with your worships.
Since ye would be such devils,
Why did you not begin with one another handsomelyhandsomely: fittingly; also, liberally
And spare the woman to beget more food onbeget more food on: i.e. Aminta may produce children which will serve as further food?
Good sir—
You shall grow mummymummy: beaten to a pulpy substance, rascals!
I'll make you fall to your brawnsbrawns: fleshy or muscular parts of the body and your buttocks
And worryworry: to choke with a mouthful of food one another like keen bandogsbandogs: ferocious dogs chained or tied up to guard a house—!
Good sir, be merciful.
You shall know what 'tis to be damned cannibals!
Oh, my best friend!
Alas, poor heart! Here,
Here's some meat and sovereign drinksovereign drink: efficacious or potent remedy to ease you.
Sit down, gentle sweet.
I am blessed to see you.
Stir not within forty foot of this food!
If you do, dogs—!
Oh, captain! Captain! Captain!
Ye shall have meat, all of you—
Captain, hear me first. Hark!
'Tis so inhumane I would not ha' the air corrupted with it—
Oh, barbarous men! Sit down, du-Pont,
Good Master, and honest sailors.
But stand you off
And touch nothing but what's flung at thee, as if you were dogs;
If you do, I'll cut your fingers. Friends,
I'll spoil your carving.

div.stage: Aminta gives food to gentlemen and Sailors.

lg.l: There, wretches, there.
Eat your meat handsomelyhandsomely: fittingly; also, liberally now,
And give heaven thanks.
There's more bread.
See, they snarl like dogs.
Eat quietly, you rascals, eat quietly.
There is drink, too.
Come, come, I'll fill you each your cups,
Ye shall not surfeitsurfeit: suffer from over indulgence in food or drink.
And what have you discovered?
Sweet, a paradise,
A paradise inhabited with angels
Such as you are; their pities make 'em angels.
They gave me these viandsviands: provisions and supplied me
With these precious drinks.
Shall we not see 'em?
Yes, they will see you
Out of their charities. Having heard our story
They will come and comfort us. Come presently.
We shall no more know wantswants: shortages nor miseries.
Are they all women?
All, and all in love with us—
How!
Do not mistake: in love with our misfortunes;
They will cherish and relieve our men.
Do you shrug now
And pull up your noses? You smell comfort.
See, they stretch out their legs like dottrelsdottrels: fools,

Each like a new Saint DenisSaint Denis: martyred third-century French saint who is said to have carried his head for several miles after he was beheaded. Tibalt implies the sailors only attend to their bodily needs and desires (Bourne).
Dear mistress,
When you would name me and the women hear:
Call me your brother, you I'll call my sister,
And pray observe this all—
Why do you change color, sweet?
Eating too much meat.
Sauced with jealousy.
Fie, fieFie, fie: exclamation inciting shame, usually said to children, dear saint, i'faith ye are too blame.
Are ye not here? Here, fixed in my heart?

div.stage: Enter Rosella, Clarinda, Crocale, Hippolita, and Juletta.

lg.l: Hark, hark!
They are come. Stand ready, and look noblynobly: splendidly, magnificently,
And with all humble reverence receive 'em.
Our lives depend upon their gentle pities
And death waits on their anger.
Sure they are fairies.
Be they devils, devils of flesh and blood,
After so long a LentLent: referring to the Christian time of abstinence and repentance and tedious voyage
To me they are angels.
Oh for some eryngoeseryngoes: aphroditic plants—!
Potatoes or cantharidescantharides: dried beetles used as aphrodisiac—
Peace, you rogues that buy abilitiesbuy abilities: buy medicines thought to enhance sexual abilities of your 'pothecaries.
Had I but took the diet of green cheese
And onions for a month, I could do wondersHad I ... wonders: presumably this diet was thought to improve one's sexual abilities.
Are these the jewels you run mad for?
What can you see in one of these
To whom you would vouchsafevouchsafe: acknowledge or bestow in some favorable manner a gentle touch?
Can nothing persuade you
To love yourselves and place your happiness
In cold and chaste embraces of each other?
This is from the purpose.
We had your grantgrant: consent to have them as they were.
'Tis a beauteous creature,
And to myself I do appear deformed
When I consider her. And yet she is
The stranger's sister. Why then should I fear?
She cannot prove my rival.
When you repent
That you refused my counsel, may it add
