To your afflictions that you were forewarned
Yet leapt into the gulf of your misfortunes.
But have your wishes.
Now she makes to us.
I am instructed. But take heed, Albert,
You prove not falsefalse: deceitful—
Ye are your own assurance,
And so acquainted with your own perfections
That weak doubts cannot reach you. Therefore, fear not.
That you are poor and miserable men
My eyes inform me; that without our succorssuccors: aids, assistances
Hope cannot flatter you to dream of safety.
The present plight you are in can resolveresolve: alter so as to form a concord you
That to be merciful is to draw near
The heavenly essence. Whether you will be
Thankful, I do not question, nor demand
What country bred you—what names, what manners—
To us it is sufficient we relieve
Such as have shapes of men. And I command you,
As we are not ambitious to know
Farther of you, that on pain of death
You presume not to enquire what we are
Or whencewhence: from where derived.
In all things we obey you,
And thankfully we ever shall confess

Ourselves your creatures. Ourselves your creatures: In this passage, Albert pledges the men's subservience to Rosella and appears to reverse the patriarchal assumptions of early modern social relations. "Creatures," in this sense, likely refers to someone "who owes his fortune or position, and remains subservient to, a patron," and who also is "ready to do another's bidding" (OED). According to Albert, then, the Frenchmen are not only willing to subjugate themselves to these women, but also are willing to do their bidding (sexually or otherwise). What makes this passage especially interesting is how quickly its effects are reversed; just ten lines later, Rosella cedes power back to the men. These quick-shifting dynamics are likely related to the comedic genre of the play, as the playwrights keep switching back and forth between giving their French protagonists patriarchal power and taking it away from them.
You speak as becomes you.
First, then, and willingly deliver up
Those weapons we could force from you.
Most gladly at your feet.
I have had many a combat with a tall wench,
But never was disarmed before.
And now hear comfort:
Your wantswants: shortages shall be supplied, and though it be
A debt women may challenge to be sued to—
Especially from such they may command—
We give up to you that power, and therefore,
Freely each make his choice.
Then here I fix—
Nay, she is mine; I eyed her first—!
This mine—!
StayStay: Stop, halt, good rascals.
You are not giving order to a tailor
For the fashion of a new suit.
Nor are you in your warehouse, master merchant.
Stand back and give your betters leave—your betters—
And grumble not; if ye do, as I love meat
I will so swingeswinge: beat, flog, or whip the salt itchsalt itch: sexual desire out onon: of you.
Captain, Master, and the rest of us
That are brothers and good fellows, we have been
Too late by the earsby the ears: gathered to fight and yet smartsmart: feel pain for our follies.
To end therefore all future emulationemulation: ambitious rivalry for power or honor, if you please,
Trust to my election; you shall say
I am not partial to myself, I doubt not,
Give contentcontent: satisfaction to all.
Agreed, agreed.
Then but observe how learnèd and discreetly
I will proceed and, as a skillful doctor
In all the quirks belongs to the game,
Read over your complexions. For you, captain,
Being first in place and therefore first to be served,
I give my judgment thus: for your aspectaspect: outward appearance, particularly the face
Y'are much inclined to melancholy, and that tells me
The sullen Saturn had predominance
At your nativity—a malignantmalignant: damaging or harmful planet,
And if not qualified by a sweet conjunction
Of a soft and ruddy wench born under VenusVenus: Roman goddess of beauty and love, here referring also to the planet,
It may prove fatal—therefore, to your arms

I give this rose-cheeked virgin.For you ... rose-cheeked virgin: As Tibalt explains how he selected a partner for Albert, he refers to astrology, saying that Albert was born under Saturn, "a malignant planet," which caused him to be prone to melancholy. In the early modern period, the medical belief in the humoral system still persisted. This meant that there were four bodily "humors": phlegm, yellow bile, blood, and black bile, that could cause various issues if these fluids were unbalanced. Melancholy was the term for an excess of black bile. The humoral system often was used in conjunction with theories about the planets (namely, the moon, Mars, Venus, Jupiter, and Saturn). In this case, Tibalt selects Clarinda because he claims that she is a "soft, ruddy wench born under Venus." This, according to Tibalt should restore Albert's balance and counteract his melancholic tendencies. Melancholy was also blamed for hallucinations, sudden outbursts, and other signs of madness.
To my wish!
'Til now I never was happy.
Nor I accursed!
Master, you are old
Yet love the game—that I perceive, too—
And if not well spurred upspurred up: ready to ride, used as sexual innuendo you may prove rusty.
Therefore, to help ye here's a BradamantaBradamanta: fictional female warrior and expert in combat
Or I am cozened cozened: deceived or duped in my calculation.
A poor old man allotted to my share—
Thou wouldst have two—
Nay, I think twenty—but fear not, wench:
Though he be old he's tough. Look on's making,
He'll not fail, I warrant thee—
A merry fellow,
And were not man a creature I detest
I could endure his company—
Here's a fair herd of does before me.
And now for a barren one,
For though I like the sport, I do not love
To father children. Like the Grand SignorGrand Signor: Ottoman Sultan,
Thus I walk in my seraglioseraglio: the part of a Muslim palace where wives and concubines live
And view 'em as I pass, then draw I forth
My handkerchief and, having made my choice,
I thus bestow it—
On me?
On you. Now my choice is made,
To it, you hungry rascals.
Excellent.
As I love goodness,
It makes me smile i'th height of all my fears.
What a strong contention you may behold
Between my mother's mirth and anger.
Nay, no coyness, be mistress of your word:
I must and will enjoy you.
Be advised, fool: alas, I am old.
How canst thou hope content content: satisfaction from one that's fifty?
Never talk on't.
I have known good ones at threescorethreescore: sixty and upwards.
Besides, the weather's hot, and men
That have experience fear fevers;
A temperate diet is the only physicphysic: curative.

Your julepsjuleps: sweet drinks made with syrup or sugar nor guajacumguajacum: drug prepared from the resin of a tree of the West Indies, prunellosprunellos: plums; also, liqueurs derived from the fruit of the blackthorn,
CamphorCamphor: a bitter pharmaceutical substance used as an antaphrodisiac pills, nor gourd watergourd water: rain water collected in a hollowed-out gourd (Bourne).,
Come not near your old woman.
Youthful stomachs are still craving
Though there be nothing left to stop their mouths with.
And believe me, I am no frequent giver of those bountiesI am no frequent ... bounties: i.e. I do not often engage in sexual activity—
Laugh on, laugh on, good gentlemen, do.
I shall make holiday and sleep when you
Dig in the mines 'til your hearts ache.
A mad fellow.
Well, sir, I'll give you hearing, and as I like
Your wooing and discourse—but I must tell ye, sir,
That rich widows look for great sums in presentrich widows ... present: i.e. rich widows expect large sums of money as gifts
Or assurances of ample jointersjointers: joint possessors of property or an estate.
That to me is easy,
For instantly I'll do it: hear, comrades!
What say'st thou, Tibalt?
Why, that to woo a wench with empty hands
Is no good heraldryheraldry: show of honor and noble birth. Therefore, let's to the gold
And share it equally; 'twill speak for us
More than a thousand compliments or cringescringes: bows, deferential acts,
Ditties stolen from PatrickPatrick: likely misspelling of Petrarch, Italian Renassiance author of famous love sonnets, or discourse from OvidOvid: ancient Roman poet of great renown.
Besides, 'twill beget us respect,
And if ever Fortune friend us with a barkbark: wooden ship,
Largely supply us with all provision.
Well advised; defer it not.
Are ye all contented?
We are!
Let's away then.
Straight we'll return
And you shall see our riches.
Since I knowSince I know: Since I have known what wonder and amazement was,
I ne'er was so transported transported: carried away by excitement.
Why weep ye, gentle maid?
There is no danger here to such as you.
Banish fear, for with us I dare promise
You shall meet all courteous entertainment.
We esteemesteem: regard as valuable ourselves most happy in you—
And bless fortune that brought you hither.
Hark in your ear:
I love you as a friend already.
EreEre: Before long you shall call me by a nearer nameEre long ... nearer name: i.e. Soon you will call me your sister-in-law.
I wish your brother well; I know you apprehend me.
(Ay, to my grief, I do.)
Alas, good ladies, there is nothing left me
But thanks to pay ye with.
That's more
Than yet you stand engaged for.

div.stage: Enter Albert, Tibalt, and the rest with treasure.

lg.l: So soon returned!

Here: see the idol of the lapidarylapidary: an individual who is skilled in the work surrounding gems and precious stones. idol of lapidary: The phrase "idol of lapidary" begins a series of descriptions of the treasure by the Frenchmen that seemingly elevates its value to a mythical quality through associations with a diverse variety of individuals—slaves, merchants, royalty, sailors—who would go to immense lengths to possess it. "Idol of lapidary" also implies that the treasure is a divine object of worship, perhaps even beyond one's love of God. While these descriptions aim to impress Rosella, in a larger sense they function to afford the men themselves material value alongside their sexual value to the women. It is therefore of utmost importance to the Frenchmen to upsell the value of the treasure. Furthermore, in a narrative with characters like Lamure, Franville, and Morillat, whose identities are strongly rooted in their material wealth (as first seen in Act 1, Scene 1 during the storm), perhaps these people-related descriptions of value mirror their own views on persona and reflect a genuine desire for such treasure to re-establish their identities.
These pearls for which the slavish negro
Dives to the bottom of the sea—
To get which the industrious merchant
Touches at either poleTouches at either pole: Traverses the globe—
The never-sailing purchase
Of lordships and of honors—
The world's mistress
That can give everything to the possessors—
For which the sailors scorn scorn: defy tempestuous winds
And spit defiance in the sea—
Speak, lady: look we not lovely now?

Yes, yes—oh, my starsoh, my stars: Rosella's call of gratitude to the stars for bringing her an opportunity for revenge subtly contrasts Albert's earlier pleas to a Christian heaven. While both reference some type of higher force intertwined with the Christian beliefs of the time, Rosella references a naturalistic force that, in a larger sense, emphasizes the women's eschewing of societal and religious conventions in their isolated environment. The women are previously characterized alongside the Greek goddess Artemis as independent, chaste hunters and with Artemis' associations with the moon. Here, the women appeal to a Greek, polytheistic religion that places belief in the power of celestial bodies like the moon and the stars. This association also perhaps alludes to the idea of women constantly changing and being influenced by nature. Taken together with the men's references to conventional Christian ideas of God and heaven, a rhetorical battle is created not only between spiritual worldviews, but also between genders.,
Be now forever blessed that have brought
To my revenge these robbers! Take your arrows
And nail these monsters to the earth.
What mean ye, lady?
In what have we offended?
Oh, my daughter
And you companions with me in all fortunes!
Look on these caskets and these jewels.
These were our own when first we put to sea
With good Sebastian, and these the pirates
That, not alone deprived him of his treasure,
But also took his life.

l.seg: Part of my present Part of my present: i.e., Part of what was presented to me by the French men

lg.l: I well remember was mine own.
And these were mine.
Sure, I have worn this jewel.
Wherefore do ye staystay: delay, then,
And not perform my command?
Oh, heaven!
What cruel fate pursues us?
I am well enough served

That must be offering jointuresjointures: jointly held estates,jointures: The original definition of "jointure" is rooted in marriage conventions, referring to an arrangement between a husband and wife to hold a property jointly so that the property may be settled on the wife if she is widowed. It also has been used an equivalent term to a dowry. Tibalt's use of "jointures," then, might allude to the societal and patriarchal need to establish order through marital and legal conventions, particularly as this usage occurs in the face of a woman's (Rosella's) anger. However, the suggested convention of "jointure" is one of the few of its time that gave women potential independence over their estate, and so it may also be rhetorically appropriate that Tibalt offers a share of further wealth to Rosella who is presumed to be widowed (Habakkuk, 15). It is also possible that jointure's associations with dowry suggest that an intense situation of environment isolated from societal norms could lead to a switch in gender roles, such as a man freely offering dowry directly to a woman. jewels,
And precious stones more than I brought with me.
Why shoot ye not?
Hear me, dear mother,
And when the greatest cruelty is justice,
Do not show mercy: death to these starved wretches
Is a reward, not punishment. Let 'em live
To undergo the full weight of your displeasure,
And that they may have sense to feel the torments
They have deserved, allow 'em some small pittancepittance: very small offering of something, in this case, nourishment
To linger out their tortures.
'Tis well counselled,
And we'll follow it.
Hear us speak—
Peace, dogs!
Bind 'em fast. When fury hath given way to reason The women tie up the men with ropes.
I will determine of their sufferings
Which shall be horrid. Vengeance, though slow-paced,
At length o'ertakes the guilty, and the wrath
Of the incensed powers will fall most sure
On wicked men when they are most secure.

div.stage: Enter Raymond, Sebastian, Nicusa, and Sailors.

lg.l: Here's nothing, sir, but poverty and hunger;
No promise of inhabitance, neither tracttract: signs of path travelled by person, animal, or moving object of beast
Nor foot of man. We have searched
All this rocky desert yet cannot discover any assurance
Here is or hath been such men.
Not a relic of anything they wore
Nor mark left by 'em either to find relief
Or to warn others from the like misfortune.
Believe it, these fellows are both falsefalse: deceitful,
And to get a little succorsuccor: help, aid, or assistance in their misery
Have framed this cunning tale.
The ship, I know, is French, and owned by pirates,
If not by Albert, my arch enemy.
You told me too there was a woman with 'em,
A young and handsome woman.
There was so, sir.

And such and such young gallantsgallants: men of fashion.gallants: Using the term "gallants" to describe the men that Sebastian and Nicusa reported being on the island is significant because it indicates Raymond's class expectations. "Gallants" is a term that describes young men as "smartly" or" finely-dressed" who are "gorgeous or showy in appearance." In a way, Raymond is reminding Sebastian and Nicusa that they had described a group of men on the island who were well-dressed, which would mean they are of the higher or wealthier class. Ironically, "gallants" is a term that is very much the opposite of what one would expect to find on the barren island where, as the audience knows by this point, there is no chance of prosperity. Because these men are so contrasting to what the island looks like and could support, it stands to reason that it should also be doubly easy to find them.
We told ye true, sir,
That they had no means to quitquit: leave, escape this island—
And that amidst their mutiny to save your lives
You got their ship.
All is most certain, sir.
Where are they, then? Where are these men
Or woman? We are landed where your faiths
Did assure us we could not miss their sights;
For this news we took ye to our mercy,
Relieved ye when the furious sea and famine
Strove which should first devour ye,
Clothed and cherished ye, used ye as those ye say ye are.
Fair gentlemen, now keep your words
And show us this company your own free pities spoke of,
These men ye left in misery, the woman.
Men of those noble breedings you pretend topretend to: allege
Should scornscorn: hold in disdain to lie or get their food with falsehood.
Come, direct us.
Alas, sir, they are gone,

But by what means or providenceprovidence: divine guidanceprovidence: The use of "providence" marks another instance where a word's non-religious and religious definitions can both function simultaneously. Sebastian could be stating that he does not know what foresight and/or supplies may have allowed the Frenchmen to guide themselves away from the island, but he could also be suggesting that some sort of divine protection and guidance may have played a part in the men not being present. This call for the involvement of or help from a higher force is the first of many from Sebastian, as he and Nicusa are accused further of making false claims, participating in the absence of the men, and finally acting unlike Christian gentleman. we know not.
Was not the captain
A fellow of a fiery yet bravebrave: fine, worthy nature,
A middle stature, and of brown complexion?
He was, sir.
'Twas Albert
And my poor wretched sister.
'Twas he, certain.
I ha' been at sea with him, many times at sea.
Come, show us these men,
Show us presently, and do not dally with us.
We left 'em here—what should we say, sir?
Here, in this place.
The earth cannot swallow 'em.
They have no wings; they cannot fly, sure.
You told us too
Of heaps of treasure and of sums concealed
That set their hearts afire. We see no such thing,
No such sign. What can ye say to purgepurge: clear from accusation or suspicion; also, to vomit ye?
What have ye done with these men?
We, sir?
You, sir.
For certain I believe ye saw such people.
By all that's good,
By all that's pure and honest,
By all that's holy—
I dare not creditcredit: give credence to, believe ye.
Ye have so abusedabused: misguided my hope that now I hate ye.
Let's put 'em in their ragged clothes again, captain,
For certain they are knavesknaves: persons of common or low status and rank with connotations of dishonesty and cunningness. Let's e'en deliver 'em
To their old fruitful farmold fruitful farm: ironic name for the desolate island, here, let 'em walk the island.
If ye do so we shall curse your mercies.
Rather, put us to sea again—
Not so.
Yes, this I'll do, because ye say ye are Christians,
Though I hardly creditcredit: give credence to, believe it: bring in the boat,
And all aboard again but these two wretches.
Yet leave 'em four days' meat; if in that time
(For I will search all nooks of this strange island)
I can discover any tracttract: signs of path travelled by person, animal, or moving object of these men,
Alive or dead, I'll bear ye off and honor ye.
If not, ye have found your graves. So, farewell.
That goodness dwells above, and knows us innocent,
Comfort our lives, and at his pleasure quitquit: leave us.
Come, cousin, come. Old time will end our story,
But no time (if we end well) ends our glory.

div.stage: Enter Rosella, Clarinda, Crocale, Hippolita, and Juletta.

lg.l: They are our slaves. Turn all those pities,
Those tender reluctationsreluctations: reluctances, aversions to cruelty that should become your sex,
To stern anger, and when ye look upon 'em,
Look with those eyes that wept those bitter sorrows,
Those cruelties ye suffered by their rapinesrapines: acts of seizure by force.
Some five days hence, that blessèd hour comes,
Most happy to me, that knit this hand to my dear husband's
And both our hearts in mutual bandsthat blessed hour ... mutual bands: Rosella refers to the coming anniversary of her and Sebastian's wedding.
That hour, ladies—
What of that hour?
Why, on that hour, daughter,
And in the height of all our celebrations,
Our dear remembrances of that dear man
And those that suffered with him, our fair kinsmen,
Their lives shall fall a sacrifice to vengeance,
Their lives that ruined his. 'Tis a fullfull: i.e. more fully felt or executed justice.
I will look glorious in their bloods,
And the most noblenoble: splendid, magnificent spirit of Sebastian

That perished by the pride of these French piratesFrench pirates: Fletcher and Massinger give us a play that can easily be read as a commentary on the greed driving European colonization. Rosella's criticism of the French stems from her view of their actions as an attempt to control their commonwealth by robbing valuable things from them. As Rita Banerjee notes, "The critique of piracy in The Sea Voyage centers especially on the inordinate desire for gold and treasure" (294). At the start of the scene, Rosella echoes Tibalt's sentiment from the beginning of the play when he tells the other men to resist obsession with riches to preserve their lives. Because she holds the men responsible for stealing her husband's treasure, Rosella intends to kill them as revenge, thus validating Tibalt's prior warning and reinforcing the critique present throughout the play that riches mean nothing in the face of death; a focus on lust for gold and treasure in the play help point out the issues with such lust.
Shall smile in heaven and bless the hand that killed 'em.
Look strictly all unto your prisoners,
For he that makes a scape beyond my vengeance,
Or entertains a hope by your fair usagefair usage: just treatment—
Take heed, I say—she that deceives my trust,
Again, take heed: her life—and that's but light neither—
Her life in all tortures my spirit can put on.
We shall be careful.
Do so.
You are angry, mother, and ye are old, too,
Forgetting what men are. But we shall tempertemper: pacify ye.
How fare your prisoners, ladies? In what forms
Do they appear in their afflictions?
Mine fare but poorly,
For so I am commanded; 'tis none of their fault.
Of what sort are they?
They say they are gentlemen,

But they show mongrels they show mongrels: i.e. they appear as dogs or persons of mixed or uncertain descent. The word "mongrel" is chiefly used in a derogatory manner, meaning that this mixed breeding is indicative of a lower form of life. This usage implies the importance of purity of nationality or race and points to an underlying conflict between the French and Portuguese throughout the play. It is also important to note that Juletta calls the Frenchmen "gentlemen," but immediately rescinds that judgement when discussing their behavior. This juxtaposition of superficial appearance with demonstrated behavior also denotes a key conflict throughout the play..
How do they suffer?
Faith, like boys.
They are fearful in all fortunes. When I smile,
They kneel and beg to have that face continue
And, like poor slaves, adore the ground I go on.
When I frown, they hang their most dejected heads
Like fearful sheephounds. Show 'em a crust of bread,
They'll saint me presently, and skip like apes
For a supsup: sip of wine. I'll whip 'em like hackneyshackneys: horses used for general-purpose riding,

Saddle 'em, ride 'em, do what I will with 'em.Saddle 'em ... with 'em: Juletta's speech here highlights a key contention throughout the play: the control of physical sustenance and that of reproductive success, both of which sustain life. Juletta is responsible for looking after her group of men: she is the one giving food to them, as well as presumably exercising sexual dominance over them, as suggested by her phrasing here. The way in which hunger, thirst, and sexual desire are regulated contrasts norms that denied women of the time a good deal of agency; the women in this play, however, are the ones in charge of all physical and sexual sustenance. Though this power is given to the Amazons and reflects an agency not typically experienced by women, their drive to reproduce was is still consistent with traditional pressures on women. As Claire Jowitt puts it, "[T]he text draws a distinction between resources needed for immediate survival—food and water—and those necessary for medium and long-term colonization—children to be new generations of settlers" (99). Though the women have a level of dominance as the food source for their prisoners and the survival source for their population, the burden of having such power is always evident. It is a burden which certainly arose within royal families when the queen was required to produce an heir. This would have been known to a seventeenth-century audience living under a monarchy. Both reproductive capacity and possession of property provide authority in the play, yet both also produce a certain level of balance. Possession and freedom are intertwined in the play—possession of riches and land enables possession of other people. The treasure initially belonged to the Amazons, giving them power, which is then supplemented by taking the men as their prisoners. But, eventually the power transfers back to the men when a concord is reached by marriage.
TushTush: contemptuous, impatient exclamation, these are poor things.
Have they names like Christians?
Very fair names—Franville, Lamure, and Morillat—
And brag of great kindreds too. They offer very handsomely,
But that I am a fool and dare not venture.
They are soundsound: physically healthy; also, morally or intellectually healthy, too, i'my conscience,
Or very near upon't.
FieFie: exclamation inciting shame usually said to children, away, fool.
They tell me
If they might be brought before you
They would reveal things of strange consequence.
Their basebase: despicable, craven poor fears.
Ay, that makes me hate 'em too,
For if they were but manly to their sufferancesufferance: endurance of ongoing pain or penalty,
Sure I should strain a point or twostrain a point or two: i.e. be flexible, even against Rosella's orders.
An hour hence I'll take a view of 'em
And hear their business. Are your men thus, too?
Mine? No, gentle madam, mine were not cast
In such basebase: low-born, not noble molds. Afflictions, tortures
Are names and natures of delight to my men.
All sorts of cruelties they meet like pleasures.
I have two: the one they call du-Pont,
Tibalt du-Pont, the other the shipmaster.
Have they not lives and fears?
Lives they have, madam,
But those lives never linked to such companions
As fears or doubts.
Use 'em noblynobly: finely,
And where you find fit subjects for your pities
Let it become ye to be courteous;
My mother will not always be thus rigorousrigorous: harsh, stern.
Mine are sailors, madam,
But they sleep soundly and seldom trouble me, unless it be when
They dream sometimes of fights and tempests.
Then they roar and whistle for cans of wine
And down they fling me, and in that rage
(For they are violent fellows) they play such reaksreaks: playful or capricious tricks.
If they have meat, they thank me.
If none, they heartily desire to be hanged quickly,
And this is all they care.
Look to 'em diligently, and where your pities tells ye
They may deserve, give comfort.
We will.
Come hither, be not frighted.
Think not ye steal this liberty for we give it.
Your tender innocence assures me, virgin,
Ye had no share in those wrongs these men did us.
I find ye are not hardened in such mischiefs.
Your brother was misled, sure,
Foully misled—
(How much I fear these pities!)
Certain he was, so much I pity him.
And for your sake, whose eyes plead for him—
Nay, for his own sake—
Ha!
For I see about him—
Women have subtlesubtle: wise, perceptive eyes and look narrowly,
Or I am much abusedabused: misguided, mistaken—many fair promises;
Nay, beyond those, too, many shadowedshadowed: adopted as a disguise virtues—
I think he is good.
I assure myself he will be,
And out of that assurance take this comfort,
For I perceive your fear hath much dejected ye:
I love your brother.
Madam—
Nay, do not take it for a dreamt-of favor
That comforts in the sleep and, awake, vanishes.
Indeed, I love him.
Do ye, indeed?
You doubt still because ye fear his safety.
Indeed, he is that sweetest man I e'er saw;
I think the best. Ye may hear without blushes
And give me thanks, if ye please, for my courtesy.
Madam, I ever must
(Yet witness heaven they are hard pulled from me).
Believe me, madam, so many imperfections I could find
(Forgive me, grace, for lying) and such wantswants: shortages,
('Tis to an honest use) such poverties,
Both in his main proportionmain proportion: physical form, and his mind too.
There are a hundred handsomer (I lie lewdlylewdly: vulgarly).
Your noblenoble: fine, splendid usage, madam, hath so bound me to ye
That I must tell ye—
Come, tell your worst.
He is no husband for ye;
I think ye mean in that fair wayI think ... fair way: I think that is your meaning—
Ye have hit it.
(I am sure ye have hit my heart.)
You will find him dangerous, madam,
As fickle as the flying flying: fleeing air; proud, jealous,
Soon glutted in your sweets, and soon forgetful.
I could say more and tell ye I have a brother,
Another brother, that so far excels this,
Both in the ornamentsornaments: qualities, characteristics of man, and making—
If you were not his sister I should doubt ye mainlymainly: strongly,
Doubt ye for his love, ye deal so cunningly.
Do not abuseabuse: misguide me. I have trusted ye with more than life,
With my first love. Be careful with me.
In what use, madam?
In this, lady:
Speak to him for me—you have power upon him—
Tell him I love him, tell him I dotedote: foolishly shower with love on him.
It will become your tongue—
(Become my grave.
Oh fortune, oh cursed fortune!)
Tell him his liberty,

And all those with him, all our wealth and jewels— all our wealth and jewels: Clarinda's promise of wealth and jewels to Albert in her hopes of wooing him acts as a dowry. In offering it, she also offers salvation as she plans to spare his life, thus enabling a future for life on the island itself through reproduction. She is actually reversing the original cause of enmity between the two groups by giving the stolen treasure back to him while hoping to attain their union, which, though she does not end up doing, represents the play's harmonious ending by marriage between groups. As Jowitt notes, "the plot of The Sea Voyage follows the haphazard and hostile interaction between these colonies until, finally, an understanding between the groups is achieved which enables them to pool resources" (Jowitt, 99).
Good sister, for I'll call ye so—
I shall, lady
(Even die, I hope).
Here's meat and wine—pray, take it—
And there he lies. Give him what liberty you please—
But still concealed—what pleasure you shall please, sister—

He shall ne'er wantwant: lack againHere's meat ... want again: Although Aminta and Clarinda have come from different groups, they work together to sustain Albert. Clarinda's nutritional provision for Albert is supplemented by Aminta's romantic/sexual provision for him, which in turn makes possible the ensuing sequence of events that ends the play in a way that ensures the survival of all involved. The idea of union between two factions is again emphasized, but beyond that it juxtaposes the threat to survival posed by division and distinction between groups, neither of which have all the necessary means of survival without the other. As Jowitt points out, it is only "Between the separate factions [that] there are enough resources to ensure a sustainable lifestyle" (99). —nay, see and you'll take it—
Why do you study thus?
To avoid mischiefs, if they should happen.
Go and be happy for me.
Oh, blind Fortune;
Yet happy thus far, I shall live to see him.
In what strange desolation lives he here now?

Sure this curtain will revealSure this curtain will reveal: Based on the structure of many early modern playhouses, including the second Globe where this play was performed in 1622, it is likely the "curtain" to which Aminta refers is the arras across a "discovery space" in the middle of the tiring house wall which would have hidden Albert from view. As Syme notes, "Even if there was no central stage door, there would have been an area between the two entrances that lay concealed behind an arras or curtain that could be drawn to reveal preset tableaux" (115).—
Who's that? Ha!
Some gentle hand, I hope, to bring me comfort,
Or if it be my death, 'tis sweetly shadowedshadowed: disguised.
Have ye forgot me, sir?
My Aminta?
She, sir,
That walks here up and down an empty shadow,
One that for some few hours
But wanders here carrying her own sad coffin,
Seeking some desert place to lodge her griefs in.
Sweet sorrow, welcome. Welcome, noble grief.
How got you this fair liberty to see me,
For sorrows in your shape are strangers to me?
I come to counsel ye.
Ye are still more welcome,
For good friends in afflictions give good counsels.
Pray then, proceed.
Pray, eat first, ye show faint.
Here's wine to refresh ye too.
I thank ye, dear. Albert eats and drinks.
Drink again.
Here's to our loves—
How, turn and weep!
Pray pledgepledge: drink or toast to it, this happiness we have left,
Our hearts are free—not pledge pledge: drink or toast to it? Why,
And though beneath the axebeneath the axe: threatened by death this healththis health: i.e. Albert's drink were holy,
Why do ye weep thus?
I come to woo ye.
To woo me, sweet? I am wooed and won already.
You know I am yours. This prettypretty: cunning, crafty way becomes ye—
But you would deceive my sorrows, that's your intent.
I would I could; I should not weep, but smile.
Do ye like your meat and wine?
Like it?
Do you like your liberty?
All these I well may like.
Then pray, like her that sent 'em.
Do ye like wealth, and most unequalled beauty?
Peace, indeed you'll make me angry.
Would I were dead that ask it,
Then ye might freely like, and I forgive ye.
What like? And who? Add not more misery
To a man that's fruitful in afflictions.
Who is't you would have me like?
Who sent these comforts?
I must tell—
Be bold—
But be you temperate.
If you be bold, I die. The young fair virgin
(Sorrow hath made me old)—oh, harkenharken: listen well,
And wisely hark—the governess' daughter,
That star that strikes this island full of wonder,
That blooming sweetness—
What of her?
She sent it, and with it—
It must be out—she dotesdotes: foolishly showers with love on ye,
And must enjoy ye, else no joy must find ye.
And have you the patiencepatience: emotional endurance; also, permission to deliver this?
A sister may say much, and modestly.
A sister?
Yes, that name undid ye,
Undid us both. Had ye named wifeHad ye named wife: Had ye named me as your wife, she had feared ye
And feared the sin she followed, she had shunned, yea,
Her virgin modesty had not touched at ye.
But thinking you were free hath kindled a fire
I fear will hardly be extinguished.
Indeed, I played the fool—
Oh, my best sir, take heed,
Take heed of lies! Truth, though it trouble some minds,
Some wicked minds that are both dark and dangerous,
Yet it preserves itself, comes off pure, innocent,
And like the sun, though never so eclipsed,
Must breakbreak: burst forth in glory. Oh, sir, lie no more.
Ye have read me a fair lecture
And put a spell upon my tongue for feigningfeigning: lying.
But how will you counsel now?
Ye must study to forget me.
How?
Be patient,
Be wise and patient, it concerns ye highly:
Can ye lay bylay by: lay aside your loves? But why should I doubt it?
Ye are a man, and men may shift affections;
'Tis held no sin. To come to the point,
Ye must lose me, many and mighty reasons—
Hear me, Aminta:
Have you a man that loves you too, that feeds ye,
The sends ye liberty? Has this great governess
A noblenoble: fine, splendid son, too, young and apt to catch ye?
Am I, because I am in bonds and miserable,
My health decayed, my youth and strength half-blasted,
My fortune, like my waning self, for this despiseddespised: scorned, disdained?
Am I for this forsaken? A new love chosen
And my affections, like my fortunes, wanderers?
Take heed of lying, you that chidchid: scold me for it
And showed how deep a sin it was, and dangerous;
Take heed yourself: you swore you loved me dearly.
No few, nor little oaths you swore, Aminta;
Those sealed with no small faith, I then assured myself.
Oh, seek no new ways to cozencozen: deceive or dupe truth!
I do not.
By love itself, I love thee,
And ever must, nor can all deaths dissolve it.
Why do you urge me thus, then?
For your safety,
To preserve your life.
My life, I do confess, is hers. She gives it
And let her take it back; I yield it.
My love's entirely thine. None shall touch at it.
None, my Aminta, none.
Ye have made me happy,
And now I know ye are mine. FortuneFortune: goddess of luck, I scornscorn: defy thee.
Go to your rest and I'll sit by ye.
While I have time I'll be your mate and comfort ye,
For only I am trusted. You shall wantwant: lack nothing,
Not a liberty that I can steal ye.
May we not celebrate our loves, Aminta?
And where our wishes cannot meet—
You are wantonwanton: undisciplined, unjust, abnormal,
But with cold kisses I'll allayallay: alleviate, bring down that fever.
Look for no more, and that in private, too.
Believe me, I shall blush, else.
But let's consider, we are both lost else.
Let's in, and prevent fate.

div.stage: Enter Crocale, Juletta, Tibalt, and Master.

lg.l: You do well to air us, ladies; we shall be musty, else.
What are your wise wills now?
You are very crankcrank: high in spirits still—
As crankcrank: high in spirits as a holy friar fed with hailstones.
But do ye bring us out to baitbait: harass like bulls?
Or are you weary of the chargecharge: responsibility; also, burden ye are at?
Turn us abroad again; let's jog, ladies.
We are grossgross: large-bodied; also, common or inferior and coarsecoarse: vulgar, unfit for your sweet pleasures.
Knock off our shoes, and turn's to grassturn's to grass: put us out to pasture; possibly also kill us.
You are determined
Still to be stubborn, then; it well becomes ye.
An humorhumor: mood, lady, that contents a prisoner.
A sullen fit sometimes serves for a second course.
Ye may as well be kind
And gain our favors, gain meat and drink,
And lodging to rest your bones—
My bones have bore me thus long
And had their share of pains and recreations.
If they sail now, they are no fair companions.
Are ye thus harsh to all our sex?
We cannot be merry without a fiddler.
Pray, strike up your taborstabors: drums, ladies.
The fools despise despise: scorn, disdain us.
We know ye are very hungry now.
Yes, 'tis very wholesome wholesome: beneficial, ladies,
For we that have grossgross: large-bodied; also, common or inferior bodies must be careful.
Have ye no piercing air to stir our stomachs?
We are beholdingbeholding: obligated, indebted to ye for our ordinaryordinary: daily meal; also, the tavern in which such meals are served.
Why, slaves, 'tis in our power to hang ye.
Very likely.
'Tis in our powers then to be hanged, and scornscorn: defy ye.
Hanging's as sweet to us as dreaming to you.
Come, be more courteous.
Do, and then ye shall be pleased and have all necessaries.
Give me some ratsbaneratsbane: rat poison then.
And why ratsbane ratsbane: rat poison, monsieur?
We live like vermin here, and eat up your cheese,
Your moldy cheese that none but rats would bite at.
Therefore 'tis just that ratsbaneratsbane: rat poison should reward us.
We are unprofitable, and our ploughs are broken.
There is no hope of harvest this year, ladies.
Ye shall have all content content: satisfaction—
Ay, and we'll serve your uses.
I had rather serve hogs, there's more delight in't.
Your greedy appetites are never satisfied.
Just like hungry camels, sleeping or waking
You chew the cud still.
By this hand, we'll starve ye.
'Tis a noblenoble: fine, splendid courtesy.
I had as liefhad as lief: would be glad ye should famish me as founderfounder: physically punish me.
To be jadedjaded: worn out by strenuous work to death is only fit for a hackneyhackney: horse used for general-purpose riding.
Here be certain tarts of tar about me

And parcels of potargopotargo: dried and salted fish eggs; bottarga parcels of potargo: Bottarga (potargo) are dried and salted sacs of fish eggs, usually made from mullet or tuna. It is difficult and time-consuming to make because it involves salt baths, massaging, and weeks of aging. The Master's joke here is doubly felt because the prisoners have no access to food at all, let alone a type of food that was difficult to make and considered a luxury. Bottarga is enjoyed more widely today, but it is still considered a delicacy (Squadrilli). in my jerkinjerkin: men's jacket,
As long as these last—
Which will not last ever—
Then we'll eat one another like good fellows,
A shoulder of his for a haunch of mine.
'Tis excellent—
'Twill be as we'll dressdress: prepare it, ladies.
Why sure ye are not men.
Ye had best come search us.
A seaman is seldom without a salt eelsalt eel: rope made of dried eel skin used for flogging, here used as a phallic image—
I am bad enough,
And in my nature a notorious wencherwencher: one who frequently seeks out the company of women, with implications of promiscuity,
And yet ye make me blush at your immodesty.
Tell me, good Master, didst ever see such things?
I could like 'em, though they were lewdlylewdly: ignorantly, foolishly given,
If they could say no. But fiefie: exclamation inciting shame, usually said to children on 'em,

They gape like oysters.They gape like oysters: This line has sexual connotations because in this era oysters were viewed as a venereal symbol and considered an aphrodisiac. More specifically, oysters were associated with vulvas. Beyond that, Gordon Williams notes that during the period a woman could be "defined through her sexual part" (982). The Master is essentially sexualizing the Amazons and reducing them to their anatomy. "Gape" is additionally suggestive in this context as it could imply the Master and Tibalt resent the women's power over their own sexuality: the women are imagined to be opening their own sexual anatomy and thus exerting control of their sexual fates.
Well, ye may hang or starve us,
But your commanding impudence shall never fearfear: in this case, frighten us.
Had ye by blushing signs—soft cunnings—crept into us
And showed us your necessities, we had met your purposes,

Supplied your wantswants: shortages. We are no saints, ladies.Had ye ... ladies: Throughout this scene, identifying innuendo is imperative to understanding the exchange among the characters. In response to Crocale, who says Tibalt and the Master are "not men," the Master assures her she will find a "salt eel" (a phallic symbol) if she should "search" them. This image is soon met by an observation that the women "gape like oysters." As oysters were understood to represent the vagina, their gaping suggests the sexual desire of the women themselves. The phrase "crept into us" makes the sexual connotations of his speech unmistakable, allowing the "necessities" and "wants" of the women to equivocate with both sexual desire and the desire of obedience from the men. Sex is then tied to power for the women as it is to food for the men.
I love a good wench as I love my life,
And with my life I will maintain my love,

But such a sordid impudence I'll spit at.such a sordid impudence I'll spit at: much of Tibalt and the Master's frustration with their imprisonment seems to be that they regard the Amazons' behavior as "unwomanly." Tibalt is willing to accept a painful death, but he refuses to accept the commanding behavior and attitude of the women in charge of him, and states that he would be willing to accept their position if they acted more ladylike and milder. Tibalt and the Master seem to have strong perceptions of how women should act, and these Amazon women do not adhere to their expectations, suggesting it is the reversal of gender roles that are key to the conflict in this moment.
Let's to our dens again. Come, noblenoble: fine, good Master.
You know our minds, ladies.
This is the faith in which we'll die.
I do admire 'em.
They are noblenoble: fine, splendid fellows,
And they shall not wantwant: lack for this.
But see, Clarinda comes.
Farewell, I'll to my chargecharge: responsibility; also, burden.
Bring out those prisoners now
And let me see 'em and hear their business.
I will, madam.
I hope she hath prevailed prevailed: succeeded in persuading upon her brother.
She has a sweet tonguehas a sweet tongue: is persuasive, is agreeable and can describe the happiness
My love is ready to fling on him.
And sure, he must be glad and, certain, wonder
And bless the hour that brought him to this island.
I long to hear the fullfull: i.e. a more fully felt or accumulated joy that he labors with.

div.stage: Enter Juletta, Morillat, Franville, and Lamure. They kneel.

lg.l: Bless thy divine beauty—
Mirror of sweetness—
Ever springing brightness—
Nay, stand up, gentlemen, and leave your flatteries. They rise.
She calls us gentlemen. Sure, we shall have some meat now.
I am a mortal creature,
Worship heaven, and give these attributes
To their divinities. Methinks ye look but thin.
Oh we are starved, immortal beauty—
We are all poor starved knavesknaves: persons of common or low status and rank with connotations of dishonesty and cunningness—
Neither liberty nor meat, lady.
We were handsome men, and gentlemen, and sweet men,
And were once graciousgracious: favorable in appearance in the eyes of beauties,
But now we look like rogues,
Like poor starved rogues.
What would ye do if ye were to die now?
Alas, we were prepared. If you will hang us,
Let's have a good meal or two to die with,
To put's in heartTo put's in heart: To fortify our courage—
Or if you'll drown us,
Let's be drunk first, that we may die merrily
And bless the foundersfounders: here used as a noun; sinking motions, drownings; also, punishments—
Ye shall not die so hastily.
What dare ye do to deserve my favor?
Put us to any service—
Any bondage,
Let's but live—
We'll get a world of children,

For we know ye are heinously provided that way;For we know ... that way: The French gentlemen, who boarded their ship as noblemen, describe themselves as almost nothing—to rogues and knaves—and plead with Clarinda to put them in any service to live, even if it's simply to help procreate. This exchange, and also the lines later when Morillat tells Clarinda to beat them if they offend them (which is an open admittance of their subservient positions at this time), speak to gender roles and the challenge that this play introduces to gender stereotypes. These men are now shipwrecked on an island where women are in charge and to which the men have brought almost no value; their own value, now, is procreative. In an era where men traditionally provide for the household but women ultimately create life, the power dynamic has been turned upside down, with both parties still depending on the other, but for reversed services.
And ye shall beat us when we offend ye,

Beat us abundantly, and take our meat from us.take our meat from us: In many instances in this play, "meat" also references a man's sexual desire for a woman's body. In The Sexual Politics of Meat, Carol Adams discusses the ways that references to meat-eating is directly linked to masculine aspects of our own modern culture (1). The Sea Voyage reflects this same dynamic throughout. For example, Morillat suggests that Albert captured Aminta for his own "appetite." Throughout it is only the men who beg for meat and seem to have this kind of "appetite." This emphasis on meat throughout, as opposed to other food sources, suggests that the The Sea Voyage is exploring the complicated ways in which meat and women's bodies are equivocated during the early modern period.
These are weak abject abject: lowly, desperate, obsequious things that show ye poor ones.
What's the great service ye so oft have threatened
If ye might see me, and win my favor?
That business of discovery—
Oh, I'll tell ye, lady—
And so will I—
And I!
Pray, let me speak first.
Good, no confusion.
We are before a lady that knows manners,
And by the next, meat I shall eat, 'tis certain.
This little gentlewoman that was taken with us—
Your captain's sister? She, you mean?
Ay, ay, she's the business that we would openopen: reveal to ye.
You are cozenedcozened: deceived or duped in her—
How, what is't you would openopen: reveal?
She is no sister—
Good sirs, how quick you are.
She is no sister, madam.
She is his—
Peace, I say—
What is she?
Faith, sweet lady,
She is, as a man would say, his.
What?
His mistress—
Or, as some new translators read, his—
Oh me!
And why he should delude delude: deceive you thus,
Unless he meant some villainy? These ten weeks
He has had her at sea for his own proper appetite—
His cabinmate, I'll assure ye—
No sister, say ye?
No more than I am brother to your beauty.
I know not why he should jugglejuggle: trick so as to deceive thus—
Do not lie to me.
If ye find me lie, lady, hang me empty.
How am I fooled!
Away with 'em, Juletta, and feed 'em,
But hark ye, with such food as they have given me:
New misery!
Nor meat, nor thanks for all this!
Make 'em more wretched—
Oh, I could burst! Curse and kill now,
Kill anything I meet! Juletta, follow me,
And call the rest along.
We follow, madam.
I must be gone now, else she may suspect me.
How shall I answer her?
Tell her directly.
That were too sudden, too improvidentimprovident: rash, lacking foresight.
Fires of this nature must be put out cunningly;
They'll wastewaste: destroy all come near 'em, else.
Farewell once more.
Farewell,
And keep my love entire—
Nay, kiss me once again, methinks we should not part.
Oh, be wise, sir.
Nay, one kiss more.
Indeed, you're wantonwanton: undisciplined, lustful.
We may be taken, too—

div.stage: Enter Clarinda, Juletta, Crocale, and Hippolita.

lg.l: Out, thou basebase: low-born; also, morally low woman!
By heaven, I'll shoot 'em both!
Nay, staystay: stop, halt, bravebrave: fine, worthy lady, hold.
A sudden death cuts of a noblernobler: more powerful, finer vengeance.
Am I made bawd bawd: enabler or encourager of sexual or evil acts to your lascivious meetings?
Are ye grown so wise in sin?
Shut up that villain. And sirrahsirrah: contemptuous address used to men and boys,
Now expect my utmost anger:
Let him there starve—
I mock at your mischiefs.
Tie that falsefalse: deceitful witch unto that tree.
There, let the savage beasts
Gnaw of her sweetness, and snakes
Embrace her beauties. Tie her, and watch
That none relieve her.

sp.speaker: Hippolita
sp.stage: Hippolita tying Aminta to a tree.

lg.l: We could wish ye better fortune, lady,
But dare not help ye.
Be your own friends, I thank ye.
Now only my last auditaudit: solemn rendering of accounts, sometimes used to refer to Judgment Day, and my greatest:
Oh, heaven, be kind unto me,
And if it be thy will, preserve—
Who is this?
Sure, 'tis a woman—I have trod this place
And found much footingfound much footing: discovered many human tracks; now I know 'tis peopled—
Ha, let me see! 'Tis her face.
Oh, heaven ! Turn this way, maid.
Oh, Raymond! Oh, brother!
Her tongue too; 'tis my sister. What rude hand—?
Nay, kiss me first—Oh, joy!
FlyFly: Flee, flyfly: flee, dear brother,
You are lost, else!
A man, a man, a new man!
What are these?
An enemy, an enemy!
Dispatch him,
Take him off, shoot him straight!
I dare not use my sword, ladies,
Against such comely foes.
Oh, brother, brother!
Away with 'em, and in dark prisons bind 'em.
One word repliedOne word replied: If you speak at all, ye die, both.
Now, bravebrave: fine, worthy mother, follow thy noblenoble: fine, magnificent anger
And I'll help thee.

div.stage: Enter Rosella, Clarinda, Crocale, Juletta, and Hippolita.

lg.l: I am deaf to all your entreaties. She that moves me
For pity or compassion to these pirates
Digs up her father's or her brother's tomb,
And spurnsspurns: kicks about their ashes.
Couldst thou remember what a father thou hast once,
'Twould steelsteel: harden thy heart against foolish pity.
By his memory, and the remembrance of his dear embraces,
I am taught that in a noblenoble: fine cause revenge is noblenoble: fine,
And they shall fallfall: fall prey as, become victims as the sacrifices to appease
His wandering ghost, and my incensed fury.
The new-come prisoner, too?
Him, too. Yet that we may learn
Whether they are the same, or near allied
To those that forced me to this cruel course,
Better their poor allowanceBetter their poor allowance: Provide them more succor, and permit 'em
To meet together and conferconfer: converse, speak
Within the distance of your ear. Perhaps
They may discover something that may kill
Despair in me and be a means to save 'em
From certain ruin.
That shall be my chargecharge: responsibility; also, burden.
Yet to prevent
All hope to rescue—for this new-come captain
Hath both a ship and men not far off from us,
Though ignorant to find the only port
That can yield entrance to our happy island—
Guard the place strongly, and ereere: before the next sun
Ends his diurnaldiurnal: occupying the length of one day progress, I will be
Happy in my revenge, or set 'em free.

div.stage: Enter Crocale, Juletta, and Hippolita, with a table, food, and wine.In early modern drama, a table itself as a prop could be considered an extravagant display considering set design tended to be minimalistic. Most of the money spent by theater companies was invested more in costumes than sets. As a result, plays during the period had remarkably spare stages, requiring the audience to rely heavily on their imagination to furnish the setting. Seeing a table furnished with lots of props would likely stand out to the audience, and suggests that the table will be the center of gravity for the scene. In other words, the action will revolve around the table, directly and indirectly.

lg.l: So serve it plentifully,
And lose not time to enquire the cause;
There is a mainmain: powerful designdesign: plot that hangshangs: depends upon this bountybounty: i.e. the food and wine.
That discovers secrets which tortures cannot openopen: reveal.
Open the doors, too, of the several prisons,
And give all free entrance into this room.
Undiscovered, I can here markmark: watch all.
lg.note: In the original text, no stage directions are provided to indicate Crocale is hiding or has stepped aside. Additionally, no stage directions specify that Hippolita and Juletta exit. Rather, these must simply be inferred from the dialogue. During this period, performances accomplished hiding characters in several ways. In the Blackfriars Theatre, for example, Crocale could 'hide' by sitting with the audience, as some of the audience in the Blackfriars sat on the side of the stage. Another place for Crocale to hide could be up on a balcony (which many early modern theaters had), watching the action from up above. The most important aspect of this stage direction is possibly not that Crocale is visible to the audience, but that the audience actually knows she is hiding.
lg.l: Here's Captain Careless, and the tough shipmaster.
The slaves are nosed like vulturesnosed like vultures: i.e., scavaging;
How wild they look—
Ha, the mystery of this,
Some good hobgoblinhobgoblin: mischievous spirit or being; can also refer to mythological characters such as Robin Goodfellow rise and reveal!
I am amazed at it, nor can I soundsound: apprehend, understand the intent.
Is not this bread—
substantial bread—not painted?
But take heed,
You may be poisoned.
I am sure I am famished,
And famine, as the wise man says,
Gripes the guts as much as any mineral.
This may be treacletreacle: curative for poison sent to preserve me
After a long fast, or, be it viper's spittlespittle: saliva, in this case, venom,
I'll run the hazardhazard: risk of loss or harm.
We are past all fear. I'll take part with ye.
Do. And now i'faith, how d'ye feel yourself? Tibalt and Master, eating.
I find great ease in't. What's here?
Wine, and it be thy will,
Strong lustylusty: pleasing, invigorating wine. Well, fools may talk
Of mithridatemithridate: mixture considered to be a comprehensive remedy, cordialscordials: comforting or reviving medicines or beverages, and elixirselixirs: liquid remedies for diseases,
But from my youth this was my only physicphysic: curative.
Here's a color; what lady's cheek,
Though cerusedcerused over: painted over, often in reference to medicinal ointments or cosmetics over, comes near it?
It sparkles too, hangs out diamonds—
Oh, my sweetheart, how I will hug thee
Again, and again! They are poor drunkards,
And not worth thy favors,
That number thy moist kissesthy moist kisses: sips of wine in these crystals. Tibalt drinks.
But monsieur,
Here are sucketssuckets: succades; sugar-preserved fruits and sweet dishes.
TushTush: contemptuous, impatient exclamation, boy's meat,
I am past it. Here's strong food fit for me— Tibalt drinks.
Nectar, old lad—Mistress of merry heartshearts: term of address often used in consideration of bravery,
Once more I am bold with you. Tibalt drinks.
Take heed, man.
Too much will breed distemper.
Hast thou lived at sea
The most part of thy life, where to be sober
While we have wine aboard is capital treason,
And dost thou preach sobriety? Tibalt drinks.
Prithee, forbearforbear: abstain from,
We may offend in it. We know not for whom
It was provided.
I am sure for me. Therefore, footrafootra: exclamation meaning 'I care not'; often used contemptuously,
When I am full, let 'em hang me, I care not. Tibalt drinks.
(This has been his temper ever.)
See, provoking dishes, candied eryngoeseryngoes: aphroditic plants,
And potatoes—
I'll not touch 'em. I will drink,
But not a bit on a marchnot a bit on march: not a bite to eat from here on (Bourne).; I'll be an eunucheunuch: castrated man, rather.

div.stage: Enter Albert, Aminta, Raymond, Lamure, Morillat, and Franville, severally.

lg.l: Who are these?
MarryMarry: expression of surprise used to emphasize what follows, who you will,
I keep my text here— Tibalt drinks.
Raymond!
Albert!
Away, I'll be drunk alone!
Keep off, rogues, or I'll belch ye into air.
Not a drop here. Tibalt drinks.
Dear brother, put not in your eyes such anger.
Those looks poisoned with fury shot at him
Reflect on me. Oh, brother, look milder, or
The crystal of his temperance
Will turn 'em on yourselfThe crystal ... on yourself: Albert's temperance will act as a mirror to reflect Raymond's anger back at him.
Sir, I have sought ye long
To find your pardon. You have ploughedploughed: figuratively tilled fields, but in this case more generally earned one's livelihood the ocean
To wreak your vengeance on me for the raperape: abduction, for the purpose of sexual violation
Of this fair virgin. Now, our fortune guides us
To meet on such hard terms that we need rather
A mutual pity of our present state
Than to expostulate of breaches pastexpostulate of breaches past: talk at length of former conflicts or transgressions
Which cannot be made up. And though it be
Far from your power to force me to confess
That I have done ye wrong, or, such submission
Failing to make my peace, to vent your anger,
You being yourself slaved as I to others,
Yet for your sister's sake, her blessed sake,
In part of recompence of what she has suffered
For my rash folly, the contagion
Of my black actions catching hold upon
her purer innocence, I crave your mercy,
And wish however several motives kept us
From being friends while we had hope to live,
Let death, which we expect and cannot flyfly: flee from,
End all contention.
Drink upon't, 'tis a good motion; Tibalt offering wine.
RatifyRatify: Formally sanction it in wine, and 'tis authenticalauthentical: legally valid. Tibalt drinks.
When I consider
The groundground: legal ground, reason of our long difference and look on
Our not-to-be-avoided miseries,
It doth beget in me—I know not how—
A soft religious tenderness which tells me,
Though we have many faults to answer for
Upon our own account, our fathers' crimes
Are in us punished. Oh, Albert, the course
They took to leave us rich was not honest,
Nor can that friendship last which virtue joins not.
When first they forced the industrious Portugals
From their plantations in the happy islands—
This is that I watch for—
And did omit no tyranny which men
InuredInured: Accustomed to spoilspoil: valuable goods, often referring to those acquired through piracy or conquest and mischief could inflict
On the grieved sufferers; when, by lawless rapinerapine: act of seizure by force
They reaped the harvest which their labors sowed,
And, not content to force 'em from their dwelling,
But laid for 'em at sea to ravishravish: carry off by force from 'em
The last remainder of their wealth, then, then
After a long pursuit, each doubting other
As guilty of the Portugals' escape,
They did begin to quarrel like ill men
(Forgive me, pietypiety: feeling of pity, devotion, and faithfulness, that I call 'em so)—
No longer love or correspondence holds
Than it is cemented with prey or profit—
Than did they turn those swords they oft had bloodied
With innocent gore upon their wretched selves
And paid the forfeit of their cruelty
Shown to Sebastian and his colony
By being fatal enemies to each other.
Thence grew Aminta's raperape: abduction, usually for the purpose of sexual violation, and my desire
To be revenged. And now observe the issue:
As they for spoilspoil: valuable goods, often referring to those acquired through piracy or conquest ever forgot compassion
To women (who should be exempted
From the extremities of a lawful war),
We now, young able men, are fallen into
The hands of women that, against the soft
Tenderness familiar to their sex,
Will show no mercy.
None, unless you show us
Our long lost husbands.
We are those Portugals you talked of—
StayStay: stop, halt,
I met upon the sea in a tall ship
Two Portugals, famished almost to death—
Our ship, by this wine!
And those the rogues that stole her
Left us to famish in the barren islands!
Some such tale they told me,
And something of a woman which, I find,
To be my sister.
Where are these men?
I left 'em,
Supposing they had deludeddeluded: deceived me with forged tales,
In the island where they said
They had lived many years the wretched owners
Of a huge mass of treasure.
The same men, and that the fatal muckfatal muck: referring to the treasure
We quarreled for.
They were Portugals, you say.
So they professed.
They may prove such men as may save your lives,
And so much I am taken with fair hope
That I will hazard hazard: run the risk life to be resolved on't.
How came you hither?
My ship lies by the river's mouth,
That can convey ye to these wretched men
Which you desire to see.
Back to your prisons,
And pray for the success. If they be those
Which I desire to find, you are safe.
If not, prepare to die tomorrow,
For the word cannot redeem ye.
However. We are armed
For either fortune.

div.stage: Exit all but Tibalt and Crocale.

lg.l: What must become of me, now
That I am not dismissed?
Oh, sir, I purpose
To have your company.
Take heed, wicked woman:
I am apt to mischief now.
You cannot be so unkind
To her that gives you liberty.
No, I shall be too kind, that's the devil on't.
I have had storestore: collection of good wine, and when I am drunk
JoanJoan: generic name for any woman is a lady to me, and I shall
Lay about me like a lord—I feel strange motions.
Avoid me, temptation.
Come, sir, I'll help ye in.
What may that be
That moves upon the lake?
Still it draws nearer,
And now I plainly can discerndiscern: perceive, recognize it:
'Tis the French ship.
In it a woman
Who seems to invite us to her—
Still she calls with signs of love to hasten to her;
So lovely hope doth still appear
I feel nor age nor weakness.
Though it bring death—
To us 'tis comfort and deserves a meeting—
Or else Fortune tired with what we have suffered
And in it, overcome, as it may be,
Now sets a period to our misery.

div.stage: Enter Raymond, Albert, and Aminta, severally.

lg.l: What dreadful sounds are these?
Fit for a bloody feast.
It seems prepared
To kill our courages, ereere: before they divorce
Our souls and bodies.
But they that fearless fall
Deprive them of their triumph.

div.stage: Enter Rosella, Clarinda, Juletta, and Hippolita.

lg.l: See the Furies Furies: from Greek mythology, female deities of vengeance
In their fullfull: i.e. more fully accomplished trimtrim: dress of cruelty.
'Tis the last
Duty that I can pay to my dead lord.
Set out the altar—I myself will be
The priest—and boldly do those horrid rites
You shake to think on. Lead these captains nearer,
For they shall have the honor to fall first
To my Sebastian's ashes! And now, wretches,
As I am taught already that you are
And, lately by your free confession,
French pirates, and the sons of those I hate,
Even equal with the devil, hear with horror
What 'tis invites me to this cruel course
And what you are to suffer: no Amazons, we,
But women of Portugal, that must have from you
Sebastian and Nicusa! We are they
That groaned beneath your father's wrongs.
We are those wretched women
Their injuries pursued and overtook,
And, from the sad remembrance of our losses,
We are taught to be cruel; when we were forced
From that sweet air we breathed in, by their rapinerapine: act of seizure by force,
And sought a place of being, as the seas
And winds conspired with their ill purposes
To load us with afflictions in a storm

That fell upon us, the two ships that brought ustwo ships that brought us: these two ships and what was on each is yet another instance in this play where gender roles are challenged. The treasures and other valuable belongings of the travelers were all aboard the ship the men, perhaps because these valuables would have been kept safe by them. Ironically, this proved to be quite the opposite; whereas the men landed on a desolate island, their crew eventually killing one another over the treasure, the women landed on the fertile island, and island containing all that they actually needed to survive. It was also said by Rosella that they became self-sufficient, learning to accomplish everything necessary for survival that they had once depended on the men for. This suggests that they did not, in the end, need men at all to thrive as a community, just as they did not require jewels or other treasures of materialistic.
To seek new fortunes in an unknown world,
Were severed. The one bore all the able men,
Our treasure, and our jewels; in the other,
We women were embarked, and fell upon,
After long tossing in the troubled maintroubled main: main sea, open sea,
This pleasant island. But in a few months,
The men that did conduct us hither died.
We long before had given our husbands lost.
Remembering what we had suffered by the French,
We took a solemn oath never to admit
The cursed society of men. Necessity
Taught us those arts not usual to our sex,
And, the fertile earth yielding abundance to us,
We did resolve, thus shaped like Amazons,
To end our lives. But when you arrived here
And brought as presents to us our own jewels,
Those which were born in the other ship,
How can ye hope to 'scape our vengeance?
It boots notIt boots not: It makes no difference, then, to swear our innocence—?
Or that we never forced it from the owners?
Or that there are a remnant of that wreck,
And not far off?
All you affirm, I know,
Is but to win time. Therefore, prepare your throats—
The world shall not redeem ye—and that your cries
May find no entrance to our ears
To move pity in any, bid loud music sound
Their fatal knells. If ye have prayers, use 'em quickly Enter Crocale, Sebastian, Nicusa, and Tibalt.
To any power will own ye—But ha!
Who are these? What spectacles of misfortune?
Why are their looks
So full of joy and wonder?
Oh! Lay byLay by: Lay aside
These instruments of death, and welcome
To your arms what you durstdurst: archaic past tense of dare never hope to embrace:
This is Sebastian, this Nicusa, madam,
Preserved by miracle! Look up, dear sir,
And know your own Rosella! Be not lost
In wonder and amazement, or if nature
Can by instinct instruct you what it is
To be blessed with the name of father,
Freely enjoy it in this fair virgin.
Though my miseries
And many years of wantswants: shortages I have endured
May well deprive me of the memory
Of all joys past, ye looking on this building,
This ruined building of a heavenly form
In my Rosella, I must rememberremember: remind: I am Sebastian.
Oh, my joys!
And here
I see a perfect model of thyself,
As thou wert when thy choice first made thee mine.
These cheeks and frontsfronts: forehead, here used plurally, though wrinkled now with time
Which art cannot restore, had equal pureness
Of natural white and red, and as much ravishingravishing: exciting pleasure or ecstasy,
Which by fair order and succession
I see descend on her. And may thy virtues
Wind into her form, and make her a perfect dowerdower:dowry, or money or property given to husband at time of marriage,
No part of thy sweet goodness wantingwanting:lacking to her.
I will not now, Rosella, ask thy fortunes,
Nor trouble thee with hearing mine;
Those shall hereafter serve to make glad hours
In their relation, all past wrongs forgot.
I am glad to see you, gentlemen, but most
That it is in my power to save your lives—
You saved ours when we were near starved at sea—
And I despair not, for if she be mine,

Rosella can deny Sebastian nothing.Rosella ... nothing: Sebastian reclaims his wife, after also proclaiming that Clarinda will be a good wife and that she will take on Rosella's virtues. Jane O'Brien discusses the trajectory of a woman's life in the period: "Whether they're mothers, ingenues or unruly woman, they are all women discovering how to find their way in the world. And it's a pretty tough world." In a way, Clarinda must now, like her mother, "find [her] way in the world," but in a form that is only granted to her by her father. So, while she may have freedom, she may also lack it, both in this scene and, presumably, throughout her life.
She does give up herself,
Her power and joys and all, to you,
To be discharged of 'em as too burdensome;
Welcome in any shape.
Sir, in your looks
I read your suitsuit: legal pursuit of my Clarinda; she is yours.
To Aminta.And, lady, if it be in me to confirm
Your hopes to this bravebrave: fine, worthy gentleman,

Presume I am your servant.Sir ... servant: The dialogue in this speech implies there will be a wedding, but no actual marriage ceremony occurs in the play. This is somewhat typical of seventeenth century comedies, where marriage is promised but not enacted. As a result, the play closes with a seemingly optimistic future, but one that has not yet come about, making the play's ending more ambiguous.
We thank you, sir.
Oh, happy hour!
Oh, my dear Aminta,
Now all our fears are ended.
Here I fix: she's mettle mettle: spirited, of strong character,
Steel to the back, and will cut my leaden dagger
If not used with discretion.
You are still no changeling changeling: changeable or fickle person—
Nay, all look cheerfully, for none shall be
Denied their lawful wishes. When awhile
We have here refreshed ourselves, we'll return
To our several homes, and well that voyage ends,
That makes of deadly enemies faithful friends.
